loans.name: Romelyn

texts.en:
Romelyn J. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 30 years old. Romelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Romelyn owns and operates a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Romelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately PHP10,000 gross a month for these activities.

In 2008, Romelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP8,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. Romelyn is requesting a new loan of PHP13,000, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Romelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings.

location.town: Thomas Claudio Ext., Dipolog City, Zamboanga del N

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de la région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font le commerce, de condiments alimentaires, d’habits et de chaussures.
Ces femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et excellent dans l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, de tissus et de chaussures. 
MINATA S., un des membres du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des paquets de condiments alimentaires.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises le plus généralement à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Fana et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Tiessiri group, all married, are on the average 44 years old, with three children; they all live in traditional extended families in the town of Fana, a sub-prefecture of the Koulkioro region (the second administrative region of Mali). They know each other as relatives and neighbors; their line of business is selling food condiments, clothing and shoes. The Tiesseri group is on their third solidarity loan; the women excel at their business retailing condiments, fabrics and shoes. Minata S., one of the group members, plans to use her part of the loan to purchase packs of food condiments. She usually stocks up in Bamako and sells her wares from her home, at the Fana market and at other nearby markets, retail, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both women and men. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs, which will be used toward everyday family expenses, with the rest reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food condiments

loans.name: Paul Ndungu

texts.en:
Paul Ndungu M. is a 44 year old taxi operator along the busy Thika road area. He offers transport services to neighbors and passersby within his area of operation. He is able to make a profit of Kshs 20,000 per month and this is able to provide for his family's needs, which includes his wife and three children. He has been operating the taxi for the last three years.

Paul joined KADET after introduction by other clients, and he has applied for a loan which he will use to spruce up his taxi van and thus attract more clients to use his vehicle.

Paul hopes to expand his business to other markets and own and manage a fleet of taxi vehicles.

loans.use: To spruce up his taxi vehicle.

loans.name: Belle Dame Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Belle Dame, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, quartier Fana coura, sous préfecture de Fana de la région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce, de condiments alimentaires, de vêtements, de chaussures, de fruits et de la restauration.
Ces femmes du groupe Belle Dame sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des condiments alimentaires, des fruits et légumes, des habillements et des céréales pour la restauration.
ASSAN K., la présidente du groupe Belle Dame compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des paquets de condiments alimentaires de diverses sortes.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises, généralement à Bamako où les condiments sont moins chers, et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Fana, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce de condiments alimentaires.
texts.en:
The women who belong to the Belle Dame group are all married, average 32 years of age with three children each and live in traditional extended families in the town of Fana (in the Fana Coura district) in the prefecture of the same name, which lies in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through relatives and neighbors and are active in the sale of condiments, clothes, shoes and fruit, as well as the restauration business. The women in the Belle Dame group are on their first group loan which will be used to buy condiments, fruit and vegetables, clothes and cereals for the restauration business. Assan K., the president of the Belle Dame group, is planning on using her loan to buy packets of various condiments. She gets her supplies generally in Bamako where condiments are cheaper, and she sells them locally in the market at Fana, for cash on a retail basis, and on credit, to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 20,000FCFA, which will be used for everyday family expenses; the balance will be reinvested in the condiment business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya, composé de trois femmes mariées et d’une célibataire, ont en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Fana, de la région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce des habillements, des chaussures pour hommes et femmes, des condiments alimentaires etc.
Ces femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les onze précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
DJENEBA T., un des membres du groupe Danaya compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter beaucoup de vêtements pour hommes et femmes et des chaussures pour enfants.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises à Bamako et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Fana et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 45.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce d’habits et de chaussures.
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of three married women and one single woman, who average 35 years of age with three children each and all live in traditional extended families in the town of Fana, in the prefecture of the same name, which lies in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through relatives and neighbors and are active in the sale of clothes, womens' and mens' shoes, condiments etc. The women in the Danaya group are on their twelfth group loan, and the eleven previous loans have all been repaid in full. Djeneba T., one of the members of the Danaya group, is planning on using her loan to buy a large quantity of mens' and womens' clothing as well as shoes for children. She gets her supplies in Bamako and sells them locally in the market at Fana and in surrounding fairs, for cash on a retail basis, and on credit, to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 45.000FCFA, which will be used for everyday family expenses; the balance will be reinvested in the clothing and shoe business. .

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Solina

texts.en:
Solina T. is from the city Dipolog. She is 42 years old. Solina is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Solina owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Solina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately PHP6,000 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Solina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Solina has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP5,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Solina is requesting a new loan of PHP5,000, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Solina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Estaka, Dipolog City, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Mrs. Naomi S. is from the barangay of P5 Carangan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, married, and blessed with 3 children all of whom are adults now. To make a living, she is presently engaged in a scrap buying business, particularly bottles, cartons and plastics. She’s been engaged in this kind business for 1 year & 6 months already and earns approximately Php2,500 a month from this business activity. 

Just this year, Naomi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Naomi, as a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, is now requesting a loan of Php20,000 as her 1st loan, which will be used to add capital to her existing scrap buying business, particularly bottles, cartons and plastics. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayments and possible business expansion.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for scrap buying business.

location.town: P5 Carangan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mind

loans.name: Bellieza

texts.en:
Bellieza H. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 44 years old. Bellieza is engaged and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Bellieza owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing boarding house rental to local community members. Bellieza has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately PHP18,000 gross a month for these activities.

In 2010, Bellieza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bellieza is requesting a new loan of PHP20,000, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Bellieza from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Julius Gichari

texts.en:
Julius Gichari W. is a 43-year-old gentleman who is married to Sarah Njeri; together they have two children. His primary business is running a butcher shop, but he also has a secondary business where he manages a taxi business. He has been a butcher for the past fifteen years, making 15,000 KES every month.

Julius joined KADET after some friends convinced him, and he has applied for his first loan which he will use to add more stock to his butcher shop. He hopes to open a hotel in the near future.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Laïdou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Laïdou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 31 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Fana, quartier Fana coura,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce, de condiments alimentaires, de boissons non alcoolisées, de céréales, de tissus et de tubercules.
Ces femmes du groupe Laïdou sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre précédents.  
ADA D. qui est un membre du groupe Laïdou compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, six sacs de 100Kg de céréales.
Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises généralement dans les villages environnants et au marché de Fana. Elle effectue sa vente sur place et au marché de Fana aux forains venant de Ségou, Sikasso et de Bamako, au comptant, en gros et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les affaires.
texts.en:
The women who belong to the Laïdou group are all married, average 31 years of age with three children each and live in traditional extended families in the town of Fana (in the Fana coura district) in the prefecture of the same name, which lies in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through relatives and neighbors and are active in the sale of condiments, non-alcoholic drinks, cereals, fabrics and tubers. The women in the Laïdou group are on their fifth group loan, having repaid the four previous loans in full. Ada D., a member of the Laïdou group, is planning on using her loan to buy six 100kg sacks of cereals. She gets her supplies generally in the surrounding villages and at the market in Fana. She sells her goods locally and at the market at Fana to fairground people coming from Ségou, Sikasso and Bamako, for cash, wholesale and on credit, to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 75,000FCFA, which will be used for everyday family expenses; the balance will be reinvested in the business. .

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Viola’s business is raising chickens, which she has done for a year.

To grow her business, Viola has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chicks and feed. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Viola hopes to generate greater profits and be able to pay for school fees and food. In the future, Viola hopes to own land and increase her business.

Viola is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her greater skills for generating income and how to be independent.

About BRAC Uganda:

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and feed

loans.name: Purevdorj

texts.en:
Purevdorj S. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two older children attend university while his younger two children study at a local secondary school.

Purevdorj and his wife have been operating a dairy product retail business in their town at the local market since 2008. His business has grown quickly within this period, and he has increased his working capital. His business earnings have enabled him to purchase land where he is planning on building a house in the future.

Purevdorj is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase and preserve more dairy products during the fall season when prices for such products are cheap and then resell them once prices climb. He will use his loan to purchase more dairy products to sell, build a house and save money for his children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve more dairy products

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet N., who is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda, is single and has no children. For the past year, she has owned and operated a retail shop.

To help expand her business, Janet is requesting a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase more drinks and maize flour in order to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, she hopes to become a doctor. Janet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to handle business and become self-reliant.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and giving Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and maize flour

loans.name: Shakirah

texts.en:
Shakirah N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. Single with no children, she has had a business rearing poultry for two years. Shakirah also sells vegetables

To help expand her business, Shakirah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase more feed for the chickens (maize brand) to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, she hopes to become a lawyer. Shakirah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by creating a job for her that has helped the family in paying school fees.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and giving Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her poultry (maize brand)

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Fatoumata T. N. est âgée de plus de 42 ans, mariée, elle  réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Mamassoni, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso.
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle décida  de s’initier à l’activité  de préparation et de vente du crème traditionnelle “Dèguè” à base de céréales, du sucre et du lait et cela depuis plus de douze ans. 
L’insuffisance des ressources propres pour bien mener cette activité constitue l’objet et la justification de la demande de ce prêt auprès de Soro Yiriwaso afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt elle est à son deuxième qui sera utilisé pour  acheter, 5 sacs de farine de sorgho, 4 sacs de sucre et 2 sacs de lait en poudre sur place. Elle vend ses crèmes traditionnelle “Dèguè” au grand marché de Sikasso et sa clientèle est composée des femmes et surtout des foraines. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour résoudre l’essentielle des dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Fatoumata T. (No 2) is a married woman over 42 years old. She lives with her husband and their children in Mamassoni, a neighborhood on the outskirts of Sikasso. After attempting several activities without success, she decided over 12 years ago to engage in the preparation and sale of Dèguè, a traditional cream of cereal, sugar and milk. Lacking the resources to carry out this activity successfully, she requested a loan from the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better meet the needs of her clientele, which is steadily increasing. Having repaid a first loan without incident, she is seeking a second one to buy 5 bags of sorghum flour, 4 bags of sugar and 2 bags of powdered milk, on location. She sells her traditional Dèguè cream at the big market of Sikasso to a clientele composed of women, mostly fair-goers. With this loan, she hopes to earn a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which will be used to cover the bulk of the family expenses and to pay the interest on the loan, any remainder to be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the preparation of Dèguè (cream of cereal)

loans.name: Nahashon

texts.en: Nahashon, a 35-year-old father of one, sells cereals such as rice and beans to earn a living.  He has been running the business for a year and a half  and   hopes to someday supply cereals in supermarkets and schools.  Nahashon became a member of Faulu Kenya through Shirley's group and is requesting his first loan of 20,000 KES to expand his business.  He hopes to open other business premises in the future.

loans.use: To expand the business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: David Mbugua

texts.en:
David Mbugua, 39 years old, is married to Ann Wanjiru, and together they have three children, all still in school. He has operated a taxi business within the Githurai area for 10 years and now makes a profit of kshs 13,000 per month.

David, who was introduced to KADET by another client, is requesting his first loan which he will use to expand his secondary business, a butcher shop in the same area, and also repaint his taxi vehicle since he plans to expand his area of operation to the central Business District in Nairobi.

He plans to buy another taxi and employ someone to drive it for him.

loans.use: To expand his butcher shop and repaint his taxi vehicle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new laptop

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina, who is 52 years old and married to a driver, has only one child who has finished school.  For the past year Amina has operated a food stall employing one person where she makes and sells rice, beef stew, tea and mandazi (doughnuts).  Her customers are people from the neighborhood.  Amina, who previously sold clothes to earn a living, is a member of a group called Happy Women in Faulu Kenya.  Previously guaranteed a loan of 10,000 Kes by the group members, she is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 Kes which she will use to buy ingredients for cooking.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Yanjintsevel

texts.en:
Yanjintsevel Y., a widow, lives with her two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai Province in Central Mongolia.  Her oldest daughter currently attends university in Mongolia's capital city of Ulaanbaatar, and her younger son attends a local secondary school. 

Yanjintsevel operates a bookstore selling a variety of books in her town, a business she started in 2003 that has become very busy over the years.  A very kind and generous woman, she is in good health and looks forward to continuing to grow her business in the future.  Yanjintsevel is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to pay her daughter's tuition and housing fees.	She says, " My main goal is to make sure my children can receive a higher education."

loans.use: To pay her daughter's tuition and housing fees.

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe BADENYA sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles polygames à MAMASSONI, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait essentiellement le commerce de produits alimentaires tels, les concombres, la pomme de terre, le poisson fumé et les oranges avec YOUMA K..
YOUMA K., compte acheter avec son  prêt  50 sacs d’orange.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché du quartier MEDINE de la ville de Sikasso et dans les vergers des villages voisins .
Elle les revend au  grand marché de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Badenya group are all married women, on the average 41 years old, with three children. They live in polygamous families in Mamassoni, a district in the town of Sikasso, in the third administrative district of Mali. This is their 7th experience with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. The loan is needed to respond to their customers’ needs; all previous loans have been duly repaid. This group of women is mainly engaged in selling food products, such as cucumbers, potatoes, smoked fish and, as in Youma K.'s case, oranges. Youma K. plans to use her loan to purchase 50 bags of oranges. She buys oranges at the big market of the Medine district of Sikasso as well as from growers in the nearby villages. She sells at the big market of Sikasso and from her home to a customer base composed of men and women, for cash. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 25,500 West African Francs, a part of which will be used to help her husband provide for the everyday family needs and the rest reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pour acheter des oranges

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en:
Lucrecia T. is from the village of Anastacio. She is 43 years old and is married with six adult-aged  children.

Lucrecia owns and operates a general store. selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 2,100 PHP a month.

In 2006, Lucrecia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Lucrecia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Heremakono Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe HEREMAKONO sont six femmes mariées  et 1veuve  qui ont en moyenne 38 ans,  4 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MAMASSONI un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que les tissus  avec  ADJARATOU D., qui  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 12 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso. Les pagnes sont  vendus au grand marché de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Heremakono group, six married women and one widow, are on the average 38 years old, with four children. They live mainly in polygamous families in Mamassoni, a district in the town of Skiasso (the third administrative region of Mali). They are now on their seventh loan from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they collaborate in order to better satisfy their customers’ needs. All previous loans have been properly repaid. The women retail various articles, such as fabrics, which is the case of Ajdaratou D.. With her loan, she plans to purchase 12 sets of wax “pagnes” [traditional colorful fabric]. She stocks up at the big market of Sikasso. The pagnes are resold at the big market of Sikasso and out from her home, for cash, to a customer base composed of both men and women. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 25,500 West African Francs, a part of which will serve to help her husband provide for the everyday family expenses, and the rest reinvested in her business. Her vision is to increase her working capital and better meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing traditional "pagnes" fabric

loans.name: Batdorj

texts.en:
Batdorj D. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both his young son and daughter, aged 7 and 8, attend a local secondary school. His wife is currently unemployed and helps out in her husband's business.

Batdorj operates a used clothing and shoes trading business out of a stall at the local market in his town. He started his business in 2007 and, in this short time, has made a lot of progress in growing his business. His wife works in his stall as a salesperson.

Batdorj used to rent a small stall but, since then, his business has expanded and he rents larger stall. He has many years of business experience and he is a hardworking person who hopes to continue to grow his business.

Batdorj is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to increase his inventory by purchasing more used clothes and shoes from Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for her agricultural work

loans.name: Doussou

texts.fr:
Madame Doussou D. a plus de 54 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs six  enfants à Kaboïla II, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de dix ans  aux activités de petit commerce notamment  à l’achat et à la vente  des bazins en teintés et  de l’encense déjà fabriqué. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Vu le positionnement de sa boutique située au bord d’une des routes principales de la ville de Sikasso, son activité marche bien.  Régulièrement, elle envoie ses bazins teintés et l'encense  embouteillé à Abidjan (république de Côte d’Ivoire) sur commande.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quatre ans et avec laquelle elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 8 pièces de bazins teintés et 20 grosses bouteilles d’ensence déjà préparé. Elle achète ses bazins et ensences auprès des teinturières et fabriquantes d’ensence de la ville de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Doussou D. is over 54 years old. She lives with her husband and their six children in Kaboïla II, downtown of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). When social circumstances prevented her from staying in school, she engaged in small business activities over ten years ago. She buys and sells dyed bazins and pre-made incense. Thanks to the quality of her merchandise, she is in high demand, especially by her clientele composed primarily of women. With her shop located by a main road in Sikasso, her business is doing well. She regularly ships out dyed bazins and bottled incense to Abidjan (Republic of Côte d'Ivoire) on order. To better serve her steadily increasing customer base, she joined the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution four years ago and is now seeking her second individual loan. She intends to use this loan to buy eight pieces of dyed bazin and twenty large bottles of pre-made incense. She buys her bazins and incense from dyers and incense makers in the city of Sikasso. She expects this loan to yield a monthly profit of 80,000 FCFA, which she will use to bolster her working capital, help cover the family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dyed bazins and incense

loans.name: Batsuh

texts.en:
Batsuh B. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children attend a local secondary school while his wife is currently unemployed.

Batsuh operates a Lotto game business in his town. His household's living standard is getting better since he began operating the lotto game. He started his business in 2008 after purchasing a new game machine. He has used his business earnings to buy new flooring for his ger.

In the future, Batsuh hopes to improve his business service. He is a very honest and calculating person who says: "I want to build a fence around my ger and yard."

Batsuh is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to winterize his workplace where he operates his game service.

loans.use: To winterize his workplace

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben is a 27-year-old married man who belongs to Mwiki Dreamers group in Faulu Kenya.

Reuben runs a taxi business and hopes to invest in his business through his savings so as to improve his standard of living. In ten years, he wants to buy a new taxi.

He is requesting 20,000 KES to buy spare parts for his vehicle. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.fr:
Née le 06 Juin 1978 à Diabali (région de Ségou),  Elizabeth C. est mariée et mère 3 enfants. Elle résidant avec son époux et leurs enfants à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Elizabeth C. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’habillements (bazins teintés, pagnes Wax,  tissus  pour d’homme) de chaussures etc il y a environ trois ans. Elle achète les bazins teintés qu’elle envoie à Diabala pour être vendus par sa maman et les pagnes Wax, chaussures, tissus pour d’homme et autres son achetés à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant d’être revendus devant le domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes. 
Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a trois  ans environ. Après 3 prêts de campagne dans une association des femmes de Lobougoula (une des zones délocalisées de l’Antenne de Sikasso), elle est à son premier prêt individuel commerçant. Tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce premier prêt individuel lui permettra d’acheter, 10 complets de bazins  teintés,  4 pièces de pagnes wax et 3 complets de tissus d’hommes. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on June 6, 1978 in Diabali (Ségou Region), Elizabeth C. is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and children in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class districts of the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). After trying various business activities without success, about three years ago Mrs. Elizabeth C. started selling clothing (traditional fabrics such as dyed damask-type “bazins” and colorful “pagnes” as well as fabrics for men’s clothing), shoes etc. She purchases dyed bazins and sends them to Diabali for her mother to sell; she also purchases wax pagnes, shoes, fabrics for men’s clothing and other items in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and sells them in front of her home and as a street vendor to a customer base composed primarily of women. She is very appreciated by her customers due to high quality of her products. IN order to satisfy growing demand, she decided to join the microfinance institution about three years ago. After three agricultural loans under the auspices of the women’s association of Lobougoula (one of the remote zones covered by the Sikasso agency), she is now on her first individual enterprise loan. All pervious loans have been properly repaid. This first individual loan will allow her to purchase 10 sets of dyed basins, four sets of pagnes was and 3 sets of fabric for men’s clothing. Thanks to this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly revenue of 70,000 West African Francs, which will be used mainly towards covering family expenses and paying her loan interest, with the remainder reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothing

loans.name: Mrs. Yorn Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people make up this village bank loan and they live in Sam Raong village in Takeo province. Mrs. Yorn K. is the village bank president selected by the other members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Yorn K., 39 years old, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice which she sells to support her family. She is a widow with a child who is studying in school. Mrs. Yorn K. sells rice and chicken in the local market where she is able to earn a large profit. Since her current business is going well, she wants to expand it. With this goal, Mrs. Yorn K. is seeking a loan to buy more rice and chicken to sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice and chicken to sell

loans.name: Lassina

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lassina O. a  plus 35 ans, marié et père de trois enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Wayerma II, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur O. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce de vente d’articles divers dont il dispose une boutique devant le domicile conjugal dans lequel il mène cette activité d’achat et vente des articles tels les Cigarettes, bonbons, allumettes, Chewing-gum, lait en poudre, thé, sucre, savon, etc) il plus de trois ans. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Il a déjà bénéficié  de 2  prêts  qui ont été tous correctement remboursés. 
Il sollicite ainsi ce troisième prêt pour pouvoir acheter 10 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes, 5 cartons du thé, 5 sacs du sucre, 5 paquets de bonbons, 10 paquets de Chewing-gum, 30 paquets d’allumette et 10 cartons de savons. Ses marchandises sont achetées auprès de commerçants grossistes de la ville avant de les revendre en détail dans sa boutique située à Wayerma I.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 170 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt .
texts.en:
Mr Lassine O. is more than 35 years old, married and father to three children. He lives with his family in Wayerma II, the central town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having had several unsuccessful businesses, Mr. O. launched himself into the business of selling various articles, and he has a shop in front of his marital home where he has been carrying out his business buying and selling articles such as cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soap etc., for more than three years. In order to satisfy ever growing customer demand, he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, around two years ago. he has already had two loans which were both repaid in full. He is requesting this third loan in order to buy ten cartons of different cigarettes, five cartons of tea, five sacks of sugar, five packets of candy, ten packs of chewing gum, thirty packs of matches and ten cartons of soap. His goods are bought from the town's wholesaler traders before being sold retail in his shop in Wayerma I. He is expecting to make a monthly profit of 170,000FCFA with this loan, and this will be used essentally to increase his business, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy diverse articles (cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing-gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soap etc.)

loans.name: Chagnaa

texts.en:
Chagnaa C. is a 50 year old widow who lives with her five children in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son, Bayanmunh, attends university and her three youngest children go to the local secondary school.  

Chagnaa has been operating a dairy retail business in her town since 2005. She sells her dairy products at the central market in her town. As a secondary income provider, she also purchases sacks of coal for 2,000MNT and resells them for 2,500MNT. She usually sells 6 coal sacks per day. Chagnaa is a very humble and quiet person and she hopes to one day have her own yard for the family's ger. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy products for increase her business working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products.

loans.name: In's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four members who live in Boeng village in Takeo Province. Born in 1965, Mrs. In P. is the village bank president who was selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their family living.

In is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land upon which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family; she also raises pigs. Because her rice field is currently infertile, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, with the remainder of the money to be used for the purchase of more piglets.

In is a widow with six children, one of whom is a policeman, while another two are seamstresses in a garment factory, and the others are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 04 Mars 1975 à Loutana Préfecture de Sikasso, Mariam T. est mariée et mère de 7 enfants et réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Sanoubougou I Kapel Kourou, un des  quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initié il y a environ 10 ans à cette activité de petit commerce notamment l’achat- vente d’habillements (pagnes wax, sacs à main, tissus brodés, etc.). Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre au marché de leur localité où ses marchandises sont beaucoup sollicitée
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt  pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 20 pièces de pagne wax et  15 complets de tissus brodé etc. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 85 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born 4 March 1975 in Loutana in the Sikasso Prefecture, Mariam T. is married and the mother of seven children. She lives with her husband and children in a large traditional family in Sanoubougou I Kapel Kourou, one of the boroughs on the periphery of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Following several unsuccessful activities she started some 10 years ago a small retail commerce buying and selling clothing (pagnes wax, handbags,embroidered fabric, etc.). She buys her products in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) before reselling them in her local market where her merchandise is in high demand. Wishing to increase the satisfaction of an increasing number of customers she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI where she is requesting her first loan. Her intention is to increase her working capital so she can purchase 20 lengths of pagne wax (typical West-African clothing fabric) and 15 sets of embroidered clothes, etc. She hopes to attain monthly earnings of 85,000 FCFA she will mainly use to increase her working capital, contribute towards family expenses and pay off her loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing (pagnes wax, embroidered fabric, etc.)

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu Z. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi, in the Kampala region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children, one of whom is currently in school.  She has a business running a salon, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Nulu has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more braids to use.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, she hopes to generate greater profits and pay for school fees and food.  In the future, Nulu hopes to expand her business further and eventually purchase a house.  She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by showing her how to learn about customers and to be patient. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new type of loan to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance, and offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more braids

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 24 years old and married.  For six months, she has been operating a retail shop.  She is a member of GNLD group in Faulu Kenya, from whom she wants to obtain her first loan of 20,000 KES.  With the loan, Caroline will increase her stock of soda, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat.  She hopes to invest in her business using her savings.  She sees herself opening a wholesale shop in ten years.  She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: to increase her stock of soda, maize flour, sugar and cooking fat

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province has five people who have selected Mrs. Nuon M. as group leader. They are taking out a group loan and each will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Nuon M. was born in 1961. She is a farmer who owns a 0.5-hectare (1.25-acre) plot of land she uses to cultivate rice, not to sell, but to feed her family. Her husband is a construction worker. She is the mother of four children: one of whom is a construction worker, while another one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending school. Although Mrs. Nuon M. and her husband work hard, they earn very little money to support their family. So, to improve her family's standard of living, Mrs. Nuon M. is asking for a loan to start a new business raising piglets.

loans.use: To buy some piglets

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi, in the Kampala region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children, one of whom is currently in school.  She has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Jenifer has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more bags of charcoal.  With the help of her loan from BRAC, Jenifer hopes to generate greater profits and to be able to buy more food for her family.  In the future, Jenifer hopes to own a house and start another business, like poultry rearing.  Jenifer is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to make money and save for the future.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old single man living with his mother and four siblings. He has owned a car repair shop in his town for the past 12 years. He specializes in car welding and body work.  His story illustrates the day-to-day challenges facing the majority of the Lebanese guys in trying earning a good income to help their parents with the household. Over the years, he has gained good experience and a good number of customers. Today, he is requesting $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy new tools in order to improve his business. In the future, he is planning to expand his shop to receive a bigger number of clients.

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Amarsanaa

texts.en:
Amarsanaa G., 36, lives with her husband and two children in Mongolia’s Huvsgul province. Her husband works at a "Just Oil" gasoline station. She used to work at a "Tes" supermarket as a salesperson. She is a very modest and open-minded person.

Amarsanaa began her taxi service in 2004 in her local town. It is a difficult business for a woman, but she works hard every day for her children’s future. Amarsanaa is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to fix up her car which is used as her taxi.

loans.use: To fix up her car

loans.name: Aly

texts.fr:
Monsieur Aly S. est marié à une femme et est  père de 6 enfants (3garçons et 3 filles). Il est né vers 1963 à Brimado et est domicilié à Loulouni, une des  sous- préfecture de la préfecture de Kadiolo, (3eme région administrative du Mali).  Il vit dans sa maison avec son épouse et leurs enfants.
Il est commerçant  de céréales depuis 10 ans Expérimenté en raison des années dans le commerce, il le mène avec  beaucoup de réussite. En plus du commerce il cultive près de 5 hectares de céréales pendant l’hivernage (sorgho et maïs).
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt  2 tonnes et 1/2 de céréales (maïs). Il s’approvisionne à Loulouni et dans les villages avoisinants.
Il vend au comptant et souvent à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de quelques consommateurs. 
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mr. Aly S. is married and the father of six children (three boys and three girls). He was born around 1963 in Brimado and lives in Loulouni, one of the sub-prefectures of the Kadiolo Prefecture (third administrative region of Mali). He lives in his own home with his wife and children. He has been a grain merchant for the past ten years. With the commercial experience accumulated over the years, he is quite successful in managing his business. In addition to his commerce he cultivates five hectares (about 12 acres) of grain cereals (sorghum and corn) during the winter season. This is his second collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, and the preceding loan was duly reimbursed. His loan will be used to buy two and a half tons of cereal (corn). He gets his supplies from Loulouni and neighboring villages. He sells for cash and often for credit (wholesale and retail) mainly to dealers and to a few individual customers. He is projecting monthly earnings of 100,000 FCFA, part of which will be used to increase his working capital and the remainder put into savings, because his ambition is to build a residential house in the town of Sikasso.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cereal

loans.name: Amadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur AMADOU K. est marié à deux  femmes et est père de 2 enfants (1garçon et 1fille). Il est né vers 1971 à KARAGOUAN un des villages de la commune de la préfecture de Kadiolo, (3eme région administrative du Mali).  Il vit dans sa maison avec ses épouses et leurs enfants à KADIOLO.
Il fait commerce général depuis 2 ans  avec la vente de céréales et d’articles divers de boutique qu’il fait durant toute l’année. Expérimenté en raison des années d’activité, il le fait avec beaucoup de réussite. 
Il est à sa première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.  Il affirme que cette collaboration  lui sera d’un apport considérable car le montant obtenu lui permettra de satisfaire la demande d’assez de ses clients. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt deux tonnes de maïs, il s’approvisionne à KARAGOUAN et dans les villages avoisinants de KADIOLO.
Il vend au comptant, souvent à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Souvent il vend ses céréales sur commande.
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à KADIOLO ville.
texts.en:
Mr. AMADOU K. is married to two women and is the father of two children (a boy and a girl). He was born around 1971 in KARAGOUAN, one of the villages in the commune of the Kadiolo prefecture (3rd administrative region of Mali). He lives in his house with his wives and their children in KADIOLO . He has been in general commerce for 2 years, selling grains and a variety of items that he makes during the year. Experienced from his years in business, he has a great deal of success. This is his first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. He declares that this collaboration will be a significant benefit to him because the amount obtained will enable him to adequately satisfy customer demand. With his loan, he plans to buy two tons of corn. He gets his supplies in KARAGOUAN and in the neighboring villages of KADIOLO. His sales are in cash, often by credit (wholesale and retail) to a clientele composed of men and women. He often sells his grains on order. He foresees making a monthly profit of 80,000 CFA, some of which will be used to increase his working capital and the remainder put into savings because he hopes to build a house to live in the town of KADIOLO.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grains

loans.name: Prak's Group

texts.en:
Four members, who live in Svay village in Takeo province, make up this group loan. Mrs. Prak L., age 30, is the group leader selected by the other members. Each will use their portion of the loan for various goals. 

Mrs. Prak L. is a congee (rice porridge) and Khmer noodle seller in her village. She is able to earn a large profit to support her family. She also raises some pigs. Her husband, Mr. Saret Khoem, is a farmer who owns a 0.2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell and he is also a construction worker. She is the mother of two children who are both too young for school. Her problem is that her home is uncomfortable to live in, but she does not have enough money to make improvements. Therefore, Mrs. Prak L. is requesting a loan to fix her home.

loans.use: To fix her home

loans.name: Chimedregzen

texts.en:
Chimedregzen R. lives with her husband and four children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in an apartment that is mortgaged through the bank. Her husband is self-employed and runs a private business. Her oldest daughter lives on her own and helps in her mother's business, while her older son works as an electrical engineer. Her two younger daughters attend a local secondary school. Chimedregzen works very hard and is a clever woman.

Chimedregzen operates a hair and beauty salon named "Anhiluun" in Ulaanbaatar. She started the salon in 1990 with only two hairdressers in Hovd Province. Her business grew quickly over the years, and her number of employees increased to eight hairdressers. Her business is in a popular spot that attracts many customers. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more equipment, tools and beauty products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment, tools and beauty products

loans.name: Aramatou

texts.fr:
Madame ARAMATOU K. est mariée et  mère de 5 enfants (2garçons et 3 filles). Elle est née le 16 Mars 1979 à KADIOLO une  préfecture de la 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Elle vit chez de son mari avec leurs enfants à KADIOLO quartier Tagouasso.
Elle fait le commerce de  tubercules, de fruits et légumes etc depuis 9 ans. Elle possède un hangars  au marché de KADIOLO où elle vend ses articles. 
Elle se fait aider par une de ses nièces. 
Elle est à son deuxième prêt  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt, 1 tonne d’ignames et 1 tonne de bananes plantains. Elle s’approvisionne  en Côte d'Ivoire qui un  pays frontalier du Mali.
Elle vend au comptant ou à crédit (sur commande et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 80.000FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et faire l’objet d’épargne car elle  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à KADIOLO ville.
texts.en:
Mrs Armatou K. is married and mother of 5 (2 boys and 3 girls). She was born on 16 March, 1979 at Kadiolo, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of Mali. She lives with her husband and 5 children in the Tagousso district of Kadiolo. She has been in the business of selling tubers, fruit and vegetables for 9 years. She has a stall at the Kadiolo market where she sells her products. She is assisted by one of her nieces. This is her second loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She intends to use her loan to buy 1 tonne of yams and 1 tonne of plantain bananas. She sources her products from Ivory Coast, a country bordering Mali. She sells to a clientele of both men and women, accepting cash or credit for orders or retail purchases. She envisages making a monthly profit of 80.000CFA which she will use to increase her business activity and to put aside in savings as she hopes to one day build a house to live in at Kadiolo

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat  de fruits

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Madame DJENEBA C. est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle est née le 19 Mai 1970 à KADIOLO, une  préfecture de la 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Elle vit avec son mari avec leurs enfants à KADIOLO, quartier Tagouasso.
Depuis 2 ans, elle fait essentiellement  l’achat vente de chaussures et de pagnes wax, bazins) et possède un hangars au marché de KADIOLO où elle vend. 
Elle  vend aussi de façon ambulante.
Elle est à son premier prêt  avec Soro Yiriwaso et compte l’utiliser pour acheter,  1dizaine de paires de chaussures, 20 pièces de pagnes wax et 20 complets de bazins. Elle s’approvisionne Bamako (capitale du Mali) et  vend au comptant  et à crédit (sur commande et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et  fera l’objet d’épargne.
texts.en:
Mrs. DJENEBA C. is married and the mother of seven children. She was born May 19, 1970 in KADIOLO, a prefecture of the 3rd administrative region of Mali. She lives with her husband and children in KADIOLO, in the Tagouasso neighborhood. For the past two years, she has principally bought and sold shoes, wax pagnes (a colorful cloth) and damask. She has a covered stall at the KADIOLO market where she sells. She also works as an itinerant vendor. This is her first loan with Soro Yiriwaso and she plans to use it to buy around 10 pairs of shoes, 20 pieces of wax pagne and 20 bazin suits. She gets her supplies in Bamako (capital of Mali) and sells by cash and credit (on order and retail) to a clientele composed of men and women. She anticipates making a average monthly profit of 40,000 CFA which will be used to bolster her working capital and add to her savings.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar S. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a ger, the traditional nomadic tent, in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Both of her children attend a local secondary school. She and her family have been living in their current home since 2005 after moving to the city from the countryside. Her husband is currently unemployed, but he operates a taxi service to support his family. He also helps with his wife's business.

Otgonbayar used to work in a drug store as a pharmacist after graduating from the Medical Institute. In 2005 she opened her own pharmacy and cosmetics counter in her stall in the town’s local market. She expanded her business by selling consumer products.

In the future Otgonbayar plans to have an extra stall in order to sell various kind of products with her husband. She is a hardworking and diligent businesswoman and hopes to grow her business and pay for both of her children’s education. She is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to purchase a large variety of products in order to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy a variety of products so as to expand her inventory

loans.name: Fadenkene Group

texts.fr:
FADENKENE est un regroupement de cinq femmes toutes mariées,  avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et  5 enfants, qui  vivent dans des  familles polygames  à LOULOUNI, une sous-préfecture de la région de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur douzième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’accroitre leur chiffre d’affaire et de satisfaire leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femme mène  diverses  activités telles la transformation du manioc en atiéké  avec MAMOU S..
MAMOU S. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  30 chargements de charrette en manioc qui seront transformés en atiéké. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et dans les villages  voisins. 
L’atiéké est vendu en détail   et en gros au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour  subvenir au besoins quotidiens  de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et de s’acheter une charrette et un âne, en plus aménager son point de vente.
texts.en:
Fadenkene is a group of five married women, who average 40 years of age with five children each and who live in polygamous families in Loulouni, a sub-prefecture of the Sikasso region (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their twelfth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of increasing their turnover and satisfying their customers. This group of women have a variety of businesses, including the preparation of "atiéké" (a couscous-like dish) made from cassava, which is carried out by Mamou S.. With her loan, the latter is planning to buy 30 barrowloads of cassava which will be made into atiéké. She gets her supplies from the market in Loulouni and in neighboring villages. The atiéké is sold on a retail and wholesale basis at the market in Loulouni to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 35,000FCFA, of which part will be used for savings in order to cover her family's daily needs and the rest invested in her business. Her ambition is to increase her turnover in order to satisfy her customers more, to buy a cart and a donkey, and also to do up the place where she sells her produce.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cassava for the preparation of "atiéké

loans.name: Soutra Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Soutra sont 4 femmes toutes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 5 enfants et  vivant ans des  familles polygames  à LOULOUNI une sous préfecture de la région de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur douzième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’accroitre leur chiffre d’affaire et de satisfaire leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femme mène  diverses  activités telles que la vente d’atiéké (aliment à base de manioc)  avec DJATA O..
DJATA O. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 30 chargements de charrettes en manioc qui sera transformé en atiéké. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Loulouni et les villages  voisins. 
L’atiéké est vendu en détail   et en gros au marché de Loulouni à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne pour  subvenir au payement de la scolarité des enfants  ainsi que les frais de nourriture de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne augmenter le montant de son prêt afin de pouvoir s’acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The members of the Soutra group are 4 women, all married with an average age of 38, 5 children, and living in polygamous families at Loulouni, a sub-prefecture of the Sikasso region (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their twelfth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso as they work to increase turnover and to satisfy their clientele. Ths group of women carries out different activities, such as selling atieke (a food made from cassava) in Djata O.'s case. Djata O. intends to use her loan to purchase 30 cartloads of cassava which she will use to make atieke. She sources her supplies from the Loulouni market and from neighbouring villages. The atieke is sold retail and wholesale at the Loulouni market to a cash-paying clientele of men and women. She envisages making an average monthly profit of 35 000FCFA of which one part will be put aside in savings to pay her children's school fees and to cover the household food expenses, and the other will be invested in business activities. She hopes to increase the amount of her loan in order to be able to purchase a plot of land to live on.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pour acheter du manioc afin de préparer de l’atiéké.

loans.name: Mariame

texts.fr:
Madame Mariame K. est une  veuve qui mère de 8 enfants. Elle est née le 18 Avril 1957 à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Elle vit dans la maison de son défunt mari avec ses  enfants à Loulouni ville.
Matrone de son état au Centre de Santé Communautaire de Loulouni, elle mène parallèlement à cette profession, des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente du bois de chauffe depuis plusieurs années. De temps à autres elle vend aussi des tasses, des pagnes et des ustensiles de cuisine.
Expérimentée elle s’est procurée d’un âne, d’une charrette et a loue le service d’un charretier pour assurer le transport et la livraison du bois de chauffe. 
Elle est à son quinzième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement dénoués. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt,  plusieurs chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe par semaine. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants de Loulouni.
Elle vend au comptant ou à crédit (en gros et en détail) à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, et  très souvent sur commande.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne afin de pouvoir terminer sa construction.
texts.en:
Mrs Mariame K. is a widow and mother of 8 children. She was born on April 18, 1957 in Bamako (capital of Mali). She lives with her children in the house of her deceased husband in the town of Loulouni . She is a matron in the Community Health Centre of Loulouni, and for several years has also carried out income generating activities on the side, notably a business buying and selling firewood. She occasionally also sells kitchen utensils, cups, and loincloths. Quite experienced and much in demand, she bought a donkey and a cart, and rents the services of a cart driver to ensure transport and delivery of the firewood. This is her fifteenth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. All her previous loans have been duly repaid. She intends to use her loan to buy several cartloads of firewood each week. She gets her supplies from the villages neighbouring Loulouni. She sells in retail or wholesale, cash or credit accepted, to a clientele of both men and women, and very often on order. She envisages making a monthly profit of 120.000FCFA of which one part will be used to increase her business activity, and the other part will be put in savings in order to complete construction of her house.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de  bois de chauffe.

loans.name: Tumurbaatar

texts.en:
Tumurbaatar S. is 54 years old and lives with his wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in Uvurhangai Province in Mongolia. His son, Boldoo, 22, currently attends university and lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Tumurbaatar started selling dairy products in a local market, and in 1993 opened a small cafe in his town where he and his wife produce quality meals for their customers. Since opening, this business has expanded, and he continues to sell his dairy products. For the future, Tumurbaatar plans to build a new cafe on land that he bought in order to grow his business. "I hope to build a new restaurant near the market, so that our business can grow 2-3 times larger than now," he says.

A very successful businessman,Tumurbaatar is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase grocery products and meat for his business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products

loans.name: Flora Manuel

texts.pt:
Flora Manuel U. nasceu no Distrito de Chokwe, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, mãe de 6 filhos de idades entre 17 a 29 anos de idade, todos vão a Escola. Fez 4ª classe não continuou devido a falte de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta seus netos que vivem com ela.

Saiu de Chokwe para Maputo onde vivia seu marido em 1980. Tem um negócio próprio desde 1989 e também pratica agricultura como forma de aumentar a renda familiar. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 2.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de outros clientes. Este é o segundo empréstimo no valor de 14.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, pedra, ferro e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa.
 
No futuro gostaria de pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir a sua obra e oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Flora Manuel U. was born in Chokwe District, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. She is the mother of six children aged 17 to 29; all of them go to school. Flora finished fourth grade but did not continue school due to lack of financial resources. She lives in her own house with her family, and she supports her grandchildren, who live with her. In 1980 she left Chokwe to move to Maputo, where her husband lived. She has had her own business since 1989, and she also farms to increase the family's income. She has no employees, and she earns about 2,000 meticais per month, which she uses for household expenses. She also saves some money. Flora has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through other customers. This is her second loan.
