In the near future, with the profits from cattle breeding, she is planning to buy furniture and household appliances for the house and a bicycle for her little daughter. 

Group members:

- Kuluipa A. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-eight and divorced. She has two sons. They are thirteen and nine years old. She earns money by providing services of making capital repairs at the school. Four years ago, she decided to start cattle breeding due to the absence of employment opportunities. Right now, her profits from cattle breeding are 2,000 soms monthly. She wants to increase the quantity of cattle she owns because it would allow her to increase her profits. Unfortunately, she is not able to purchase additional cattle, therefore she has applied for a loan in order to have an access to additional funds. With the profits from cattle breeding, Kuluipa is planning to buy household appliances for her house. With future profits, she is planning to buy a one-room flat, a computer for her children, and a bicycle. 

- Asanbai M. is fifty and divorced. He lives alone. Right now, he is a guard for the local administration. At the same time, he earns additional money by making capital repairs. He started providing capital repairs to peple in 2008 and he receives 2000 soms monthly additional from it.  Asanbai is planning to buy construction materials and make capital repairs at his own house in order to make it more comfortable. Still, he needs money for purchases. Therefore he has applied for a loan. In the near future, he plans to start construction of new house on the area that he already bought. 

- Elmira K. is forty-two and married. She has three children: her sons are twenty and twelve and her daughter is seventeen. Her elder son is a student at the Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, her daughter and youngest son go to school. For the past three years she has been a farmer and cattle-breeder. She applied for a loan for 25,000 soms previously and bought cattle. She fattened and resold the cattle and made good money on it. Therefore, she decided t continue. Now, she makes 10,000 soms monthly from it. She is applying for a loan to have funds for purchasing additional cattle for breeding. With the help of the profits from cattle breeding, she will be able to pay the tuition fee for he son at the Academy of Internal Affairs. She is planning that by enlarging her cattle herd she will be able to increase her profits, and therefore pay the tuition fees of her daughter when she enters an institution of higher education. For now, her plan is to save money for her daughter's education. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (staying environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing cattle

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda S. is from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Emelda is married and has two school-aged children. Emelda owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling cell phone electronic loads for different networks in the local community. Emelda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Emelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5,000 PHP and was used to invest in renovating the business.

Emelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional electronic loads to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional electronic loads to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
This is Helen O., 47, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Felix O., a charcoal dealer, and the mother of four children. One of their children is already working; one is in college, and the other two are in high school. By the grace of God, Helen has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her two youngest children to college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Helen as she herself has been a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Helen operates a charcoal retailing business. In the Philippines, many still use the old ways of cooking (on an earthen stove where charcoal is used) to save money. Charcoal is much cheaper than LPG fuel, which in the current market costs as much as 600 Philippine pesos (PHP), so many people prefer to buy charcoal, which is so cheap that it can be bought for 5 PHP per pack. More people are also switching to firewood, which can be foraged or found in the trash. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 8,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of charcoal in sacks to be repackaged and retailed to her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Helen dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her family and community with her as she continues to serve the Lord Almighty through her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of charcoal in sacks to be repackaged and retailed to her customers

loans.name: Gulbaira's Group

texts.en:
Gulbaira A. is the leader of this group. She is forty-three and married. She has four children: her sons are nineteen and fifteen, her daughters are eighteen and twelve. All her children go to school. Her husband is a construction worker. In addition to doing construction work, her husband also breeds cattle. Gulbaira is a worker at the local hospital. 

Twenty years ago, she spent 7,000 soms on the purchase of cattle for breeding. Since that time, she has significantly increased the size of her herd and makes 8,000 soms each month on cattle breeding. With the profits from cattle breeding, she will be able to pay tuition fees for their children at institutions of higher education. She is planning to save some money to pay for the higher education of her youngest children. To do this, she plans to help her husband increase number of cattle in order to increase her profits from cattle breeding. Therefore, she applies for a loan. She is planning to purchase additional cattle on the loan received. 

Group members:

- Nurzhamilia Z. is treasurer of the group. She is forty-eight and a widow. She has two daughters and a son. Her daughters are eleven and five years old. Her elder daughter goes to school and her younger daughter goes to kindergarten “Kelechek”. She sells convenience goods at her small shop. Three years ago, her friend suggested she start selling convenience goods because she already had a free place for a shop. So she started selling convenience goods with an initial investment of 60,000 soms. Now, she makes 20 000 soms by selling convenience goods. On the profits from her business, she was able to send her son to an Islamic institution in Pakistan. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase goods and increase her turnover. On the profits from her business, she is planning to expand her business and marry her elder son. 

- Sharshenaly A. is forty one and married. He has three sons. They are fifteen, thirteen and nine years old. All of them go to school. He is hairdresser. He has his own hairdressing salon. In 2000, he finished hairdresser courses and negotiated the rent of a room where he started providing hairdresser services. He has worked for ten years in his own hairdressing salon, which he opened with initial investment of 15,000 soms. Now he makes 8,000 soms monthly.  With the help of the profits from the business, he was able to buy cattle for 10,000 soms. He could increase the size of his cattle herd and he wants to go further. He wants to buy additional cattle for breeding. Therefore he is applying for a loan. With the profits from cattle breeding, he plans to buy a big house for his family, as well as a car. 

- Chynara A. is thirty-three and married. She has four children: her daughters are nine, six and one, and her son is eleven years old. Her elder son and daughter go to school and her youngest two daughters are at home. Her husband is a construction worker in Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). When her husband decided to move to Bishkek in search of employment opportunities, she (upon the suggestion of a friend) decided to start selling convenience goods. She started two years ago with an initial investment of 35,000 soms. Now she makes 15,000 soms monthly. With the profits from her business, she bought furniture and household appliances for her house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional goods and increase her turnover. Through the increase of her turnover, she will be able to increase her profits. In the near future, she is planning to finish construction of their new house and purchase additional new furniture for her new house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing cattle

loans.name: Nina's Group

texts.en:
Nina B. is leader of this group. She is fifty-five and divorced. She lives alone. She is a teacher at the local school and she also makes additional money through selling rolls and buns that she makes herself. She started her business of making and selling rolls and buns with an initial investment 1,000 soms. Now, she earns 10,500 soms by making and selling rolls and buns. She wants to increase her turnover and buy some equipment therefore she has applied for a loan. In the future, she is planning to buy furniture for her house and a new refrigerator. 

Group members:

- Gulnara A. is treasurer of this group. She is thirty-nine and divorced. She has a five-year-old son. He goes to kindergarten “Kelechek”. She is a teacher at the local school. Also, she provides additional courses for interested students and sells children’s books. On the profits from additional sources, she could provide for her son. Now she is planning to increase her turnover therefore she has applied for a loan. Also, she is planning to start cattle breeding in order to make additional money. In the near future, she is planning to open a book shop and make some repairs at her house.

Malik R. is twenty-six and single. He is a teacher at the local school. He also breeds cattle. He started cattle breeding upon the suggestion of a friend. He started cattle breeding two years ago with initial investment of 10,000 soms. Now, he makes 800 soms on cattle breeding. With the profits from cattle breeding he provides for his mother. There is a decrease in the price of cattle therefore he wants to purchase more cattle now. Unfortunately, he doesn’t have sufficient funds, so he applied for a loan. He plans to fatten and resell the cattle at a higher price. With the profits received from cattle breeding, he plans to buy a car and save some money for his wedding. 

- Tatiana K. is fifty-eight and married. Her husband is a car mechanic. Also, he sells car parts at the shop that is located at the car repair shop.  With the help of her husband, Tatiana breeds cattle. They started cattle breeding fifteen years ago with an initial investment of 3,500 soms. Their monthly income from cattle breeding is 9,000 soms. With the profits from cattle breeding and the car shop, they bought furniture and household appliances. They are applying for a loan in order to buy car parts to increase their turnover in the shop and purchase cattle for breeding. In the future with the profits from their business, she is planning to buy a flat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing food production equipment

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma R., a 49-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. Married to Renato R., a salesman, she is the mother of three children, one of whom is already working; another is in high school, while the youngest is enrolled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Norma has managed to support her oldest child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college, a dream of most Filipino parents like Norma, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave to their children.

Norma operates a buy-and-sell business, purchasing general merchandise from wholesalers and then selling it piecemeal for a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other similar products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Norma is requesting a Php14,000 loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Norma dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business, and she also hopes to have her own house someday. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Each fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Ester

texts.en: Ester M. is from the village of Tapon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 57 years old and is married with eight adult children. Ester owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies like boiled bananas in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Ester joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Ester is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Mamile's Group

texts.en: Mamile O. is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married with a daughter and a son, both of them at school. Her husband works in construction. In order to make money, Mamile takes orders and sews national clothes and sells dressmaking supplies. She started this activity four years ago with an initial investment of 4,000 soms and now makes 8,000 soms per month. She is also engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan, Mamile wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to increase the number of her cattle and save money to provide her children with a good education. The other group members are: Sapargul K. is treasurer of the group. She is forty-three and married with three children: her elder daughter is sixteen, her elder son is thirteen and her youngest daughter is two years old. Her elder daughter and son go to school and her youngest daughter is at home. Her husband is a salesman. Sapargul helps her husband in selling lime. Before, her husband was assisting his friend in selling lime but, five years ago, he decided to start selling it himself. His initial investment was only 2,000 soms but now they receive 10,000 soms monthly. Sapargul is applying for a loan in order to increase their turnover, using the loan to purchase more lime. In the future, they are planning to reinvest all their money in the purchase of lime. Indira S. is thirty-eight and married with three children: her daughter is sixteen, her second, a son, is twelve and her youngest son, is two years old. Her daughter and her elder son go to school and her youngest son is at home. Her husband is a meat supplier while Indira works at a sewing workshop and in a café called “Tofic”. Twelve years ago, her parents gave her a calf on the birthday of her son and she decided to start cattle breeding with that calf. Since that time, they have significantly increased the quantity of their cattle and have sold some. Now, they have a milk cow and two calves. Cattle breeding brings them 14,500 soms monthly. Indira is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle to continue their cattle breeding business. Beishebiubiu O. is fifty-seven and married with a son twenty-two years old. Her son works abroad. Her husband is a guard at a local school while Beishebiubiu is a housewife who breeds cattle while she is at home. She started cattle breeding three years ago with an initial investment of 1,000 soms and now makes 10,000 soms. She plans to increase the number of her cattle and therefore she is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle for breeding purposes. With the profits from cattle breeding, she is planning to buy a car. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle for breeding

loans.name: Shiela

texts.en: Shiela J. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old and is single with two infant children. Shiela owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Shiela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Shiela is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Alfreda

texts.en: Alfreda S. is a widow who lives in Barangay Ticad, Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a food-vending business. She has eleven children aged between 22 and 42 years. Alfreda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past twelve loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Alfreda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 56,000, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan, Alfreda is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her business, while some she gave to her daughter who is looking for a job, and some she will continue to save for future capital and for tuition fees. Alfreda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell and to assist her daughter

loans.name: Trust Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
B. Vincent is 33 years old, is happily married, and is blessed with four buoyant children.

To take all his family responsibilities within a manageable stride, Vincent plies his retail trade in Terere village, Mukono. For the last year, this has been his and his family’s, main means of livelihood. He also does some building.

In a week, Vincent says he can make up to 150,000 shillings as profits. The experienced stock in trade he has banked on to achieve longevity in his business has been his exemplary customer care skills and his efficiency. Before all this had came to fruition, he was more inclined to building.

Vincent belongs to Trust Development Group. With this loan, he wants to buy more retail stock for his shop: he wants to buy more bags of sugar, salt, rice and beans.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar, salt, rice and beans for his shop

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: Kalsoom lives in the small city of Kasur in Punjab province, Pakistan, and known for its leather industry. Kalsoom is 34 years old and married to R. A. who has a shoe-making business. He collects orders from different factories and shoe shops and provides them with finished goods. He has operated this business from his home for the last 20 years. His shoes are very famous among his customers due to their quality and durability. Kalsoom is a housewife but she gives full support to her husband and in her spare time she helps him in his business by making shoes. They have two sons and five daughters — all of them in school except the youngest daughter who is just two. Kalsoom has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy raw materials such as nails, shoe polish, and leather in larger quantities to produce more shoes. She is very confident that the family business will be improved by investing money in it.  She is a regular  borrower of Asasah and is in her second loan cycle. She has been found to be a responsible person who paid her installments on time and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for shoe-making business

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta C. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 60 years old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Vicenta owns a business selling snacks and other delicacies in the local. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Vicenta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to invest in expanding the business. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Vicenta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 45-year-old married man living in Nabatieh with his wife and four children. He has sold chickens since 2005,  and his clients all approve of his good-quality products. Mahmoud owns the only chicken store in his region so his clients are happy not to have to go to the nearby village to buy chicken. Mahmoud is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to develop his business by buying more chickens, eggs, and necessary business supplies. He hopes to own a farm of his own some day where he can raise his own chickens.

loans.use: To develop his business

loans.name: Mutojo Tukwatanise, Kihihi Group

texts.en: Watson N. of the Mutojo Tukwatanise group is a hard working married father of 5 children who has been operating a bar business for over 10 years in the Katete Trading Centre, Kihihi. He says he started his business with his small amount of savings he had from selling goats. With his savings, he was able to begin selling the local Ugandan brew known as waragi. Watson describes his customers as good, as they give him a daily ready market for his soft drinks, beers and local brews which he sells at his bar. Since he is currently faced with the big challenge of having only a small amount of stock, he has decided to ask for this loan which will help him purchase more inventory and therefore improve his sales revenue.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory (beverages).

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy M., 20 years old, is married and is the mother of an infant. She is from the village of Agoho in Mambajao municipality, Camiguin Province, located on the Mindanaho islands. Joy sells health and medicinal products to the local community. She has been in business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to invest in expanding her business. Joy is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use all additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mẫn

texts.en:
Mẫn Thị D. is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She lives in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. Mẫn runs a recycling service in which she hauls away junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. She has been in business for over six years and earns approximately 2,500,000 VND a month.

In 2009 Mẫn joined SEDA to gain access to its financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA which she used to invest in expanding the business. Mẫn is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used for the same purpose. She plans to use all additional revenue to further improve and expand her business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen is 40 years old and was married to A. W. twelve years ago. She is the mother of seven children, two sons and five daughters. None of them could get an education due to financial constraints. She and her family live in a small city called Kasur which is located near Lahore, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its leather industry.

Parveen’s husband makes shoes. He receives orders from different shoe shops and factories and fulfills orders on time to earn money. Parveen is a housewife, but she also supports her husband in his business by making shoes. She learned this skill from him, and now she has become an expert in this art. Parveen’s elder son and daughter also help their father in his business.

Parveen has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband because he obtained a large order, and to fulfill it on time he requires more raw materials. With the loan he will buy such things as nails, shoe polish and leather in larger quantities, thus enabling him to fulfill the larger order and to maintain a good reputation by it.

Parveen is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her third loan cycle. In previous years she has paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings. Parveen hopes that fulfillment of this order will make them huge profits and that their financial conditions will be far improved.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her husband's shoemaking business

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia B. is from the village of San Jose, Mambajao, Camiguin, Province. She is 45 years old. Sonia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs to sell. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Sonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
M. Nguyễn Thị (20201020056) is a 43 year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  M. is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they both are responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm Xá nhóm 15 (Nhóm 15 ).

M. is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, she raises pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 2.200.000 VND a month.

In 2009, M. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. M. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA which was used to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to purchase pig feed & other supplies. The loan will be the second taken out by M. from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand herbusiness.

About the other borrower in the group:

Nguyễn Thị L. (0) is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


M. Nguyễn Thị (20201020055) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  M. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 2 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Nghiêm Xá nhóm 15 (Nhóm 15 ).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  M. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, M. kiếm được khoảng 2.200.000 VND.  Vào 2009, M. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  M. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị L. (0) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne B. is from the village of Letican, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 25 years old and married with four small children. To make a living, Anne owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products. Anne has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Anne joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Anne from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Nghiêm

texts.en:
H. Nghiêm Thị (20201020055) is a 50 year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. She is married and has three adult children. To making a living, H. owns a specialized retail store selling metal and metal-related products. H. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3.500.000 VND a month.

In 2009, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA which was used to purchase additional products to sell. H. is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the second taken out by H. from SEDA.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm kim loại & có liên quan đến kim loại trong cộng đồng địa phương.  H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.500.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2009, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  H. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  H. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20201020054), 43, lives in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. A married mother of two adult-aged children, L. owns and operates a butcher shop whose main income is derived from butchering and selling pork in the local community. Engaged in this business for over 21 years, she earns approximately 3.200.000 VND a month.

In 2009, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA that was used to invest in expanding the business, she is now requesting a new loan, her second, of 8.288.000 VND to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim lives in a small city near Lahore, Pakistan called Kasur, which is known for its leather industry. She is 40 years old, married to M. A. and is the mother of three sons and two daughters. She lives in a three room brick house with her family. Shamim is a business woman who operates a business selling bangles. She sells bangles from her home, collects orders from different jewelry shops and supplies the bangles to them to make an income. She also sells bangles to her neighboring community and earns a good profit. 

Shamim couldn’t educate her children, except for her 12 year old son who reads to the 5th standard. It was not possible for her to afford his school fees but now her current business situation makes it possible for her to bear his education expenses. Her eldest daughter keeps herself busy doing household chores, while her eldest son supports the family financially by working in a shoe factory which pays a monthly wage. The other two are free and don't do anything. 

Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her bangles selling business. With the loan amount she will buy bangles in bulk because Eid, the Muslim holiday which marks the end of Ramadan is approaching and she has a large order to fulfill. Bangles are in high demand for the Eid celebrations and there is potential for making a lot of income. Shamim is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 2nd loan cycle. For her previous loans she maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To purchase bangles to fulfill a large order.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
Lý Nguyễn Thị (20201020047) is a 25-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. Lý is the leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm Xá nhóm 03 (Nhóm 03).

Lý is married and has 2 school-age children. To making a living, Lý provides recycling services. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Lý has been engaged in this business for over a year and earns approximately 2,300,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lý joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lý has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,496,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. Lý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.
