Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng T.t. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ giết mổ & bán T.t heo trong cộng đồng địa phương. L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 17 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 2.800.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2007, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. L. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. L. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. .

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Kanyashande Bataka Kwetungura, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Provia T. belongs to the Kanyashande Bataka Kwetungura group in Kihihi. Her main source of livelihood for the past three years has been selling goods like maize and millet in the Kanyanshande trading centre in Kihihi. It is with earnings from this business that this hardworking and determined lady has managed to sustain her family of four children. This 35-year-old dynamic business woman has reached a point where profits accruing to her business now amount to 280,000 UGX a month. With steady progress in the growth of her small enterprise, Provia reckons her prospects are rising with every passing day.

With a loan coming her way, Provia is convinced that she will be able to buy more cash crops like maize and beans so that she does not run short of stock and supplies. This will improve her sales revenue and enable her to live a self-sustaining life. She looks to educating her children so they will become important people who can support themselves in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en: Bilal is a 41-year-old married father of two children from Nabatieh, Lebanon, and has worked as a shoe repairer, his only means of earning a living, for a long time. Bilal, a client in very good standing with AL Majmoua, is requesting his third loan in order to buy a new professional shoe sewing machine which will improve his quality of work and lead to an increased number of clients and income. Both his experience and perfectionism account for his client base, and he hopes one day to open a shoe factory to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy a new professional shoe sewing machine

loans.name: Ramazan

texts.en:
Ramazan lives in a small city called Kot Radha Kishan which is located near Lahore in Punjab, Pakistan, and is famous for its dairy industry. She has been living in the area of Muhallah Jaj Wala with her family for the last twenty-five years. Her husband’s name is K. B. and he is a 56-year-old retired government employee. After his retirement, he chose driving as a profession and took the loan from Asasah to buy the wagon.

Ramazan is 56 years old. She is a housewife who spends most of her time staying at home looking after her household responsibilities. She is the mother of two sons and a daughter: her sons left their education early and started working to financially support the family; her elder son is a driver who drives someone else’s rickshaw and her younger son is also a driver.

Ramazan has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will pay off the remaining installments of his wagon because the previous loan was not enough to buy it. By doing this, the wagon will become his own property and he will be able to work without any tension.

Ramzan is a regular loan user of Asasah. In her previous loan she has paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To pay off the remaining installments of her husband's wagon

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en: H. Nguyễn Thị (20201020104) is a 34-year-old female living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong, Tỉnh Bắc Ninh. She is the group leader of this six-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm Xá 3 nhóm 19 (Nhóm 19). H. is married and has three school-aged children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,100,000 VND a month. H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase a transport vehicle to improve her business. The loan will be her first from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Nghiêm Thị D. (0) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tính (0) is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 3. Nghiêm Thị Q. (0) is a 22-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 4. Nghiêm Thị Huệ (0) is a 41-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food. 5. Nguyễn Thị Tỵ (0) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** H. Nguyễn Thị (20201020104) là 34 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh. H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Nghiêm Xá 3 nhóm 19 (Nhóm 19). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh D. chủ yếu từ bán thức ăn nhanh & những loại thực phẩm cao cấp khác trong cộng đồng địa phương. H. thực hiện công việc kinh D. này trong hơn 8 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 2.100.000 VND. H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh D. của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nghiêm Thị D. (0) là 29 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Nguyễn Thị Tính (0) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 3. Nghiêm Thị Q. (0) là 22 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 4. Nghiêm Thị Huệ (0) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 5. Nguyễn Thị Tỵ (0) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các D. Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a transport vehicle to expand her business

loans.name: Filomina

texts.en: Filomina S. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 59 years old and is widowed with eleven adult children. Filomina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Filomina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Filomina is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: Alicia A. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old and is married with two adult children. Alicia owns and operates a furniture-making business, primarily making and selling bedroom furniture to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Elda

texts.en: Elda A. is from the village of Catohugan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old and is married with six adult children. Elda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Elda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Tural

texts.ru:
Tural A. 25 let. On jenat i imeyet dochku 3 let kotoroya xodit v detskiy sadik. Tural i yeqo semya jivut v Fizuli regione.

Tural uje 4 qoda kak zanimayetsya prodajey produktov. Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca kotoriy imel svoy maqazit po prodaje produktov dnevnoqo upotrebleniya. Tural seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Tural A. is twenty-five years old. He's married and has one daughter of three, who goes to kindergarten. They live in the Fuzuli region of Azerbaijan. Four years ago he began selling food products; a business which he learned from his father, who had owned a store. Tural is asking for a loan of 2000 AZN in order to buy more goods and expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en: Danilo A. is from the village of Tangaro, Catarman, Camiguin Province. He is 58 years old and is widowed with six school-aged children. Danilo owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling cellphone accessories and electronic products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Danilo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Danilo is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be his 2nd from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida M. is from the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 34 years old and is married with three infant children. Leonida owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her 6th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong T. N. is a 53-year-old woman with two children who are studying at vocational schools.

Huong is a farmer and her main activities are growing rice and corn, and raising chickens. Her agricultural products are used to meet the demand for food for the family but a portion is sold to generate a daily income.

Huong joined the loan program in 2006 and has made very effective use of her loans in her business. Currently, she wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to buy fertilizer and seed.

loans.use: To buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Bernandita

texts.en: Bernandita B. is from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 58 years old and is married with two adult children. Bernandita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling motor parts and fuel for vehicles like gasoline in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Bernandita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Bernandita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong T. N. is 45 years old and lives with her family in Luc Canh hamlet. Her two children are still going to high school.

After losing her job in 2006, Huong borrowed money to invest in raising livestock. She is currently raising 300 chickens for eggs which she sells to generate a daily income.

Participating in the loan program since 2006, Huong has always repaid on time. She needs to borrow 5,886,000 VND to buy feed for her chickens.

loans.use: To buy feed for her chickens

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
This is Imelda G., 42, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. A high school graduate, and able to raise her two children as a single mother.  One child is still studying in public high school and the other one is already working. 

Imelda operates a variety store (in the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five PHP’s worth of cooking oil, or an egg). She earns a living by buying supplies wholesale and selling them at retail. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 11,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

She hopes that her kids will have a comfortable and well-off future. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon. A mother of 2 young children, she started a business selling clothes and lingerie from her home in 2006. Today, she is the proud owner of a small clothing shop. She is asking for a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve her store’s furnishings; she wants to purchase shelves and shop windows to present her clothes to her customers. She has been working hard in her store to achieve her goals. She hopes that with the new furnishings both her income and her sales volume will be increased.

loans.use: to purchase shelves and shop windows

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa is  43 years old. Her two children are still going to high school and secondary school. She has a shop that sells chicken meat in the village market. Each day, she can have 130,000 VND  profit  from  her  sales activities, so she has been able to maintain it for 4 years. Participating in the credit program   has helped her a lot in developing capital. Currently, she wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to invest in these trading activities.

loans.use: Invest in trading activities

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
This is Lucena C., 45, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Francisco C., a Community Marshall. Lucena and her husband are blessed in their marriage to have good health and strong physiques, which enable them to work hard for their future together.

Lucena operates a buy-and-sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell it piecemeal for a small profit. Her products range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other like products. Customers are attracted by the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the loC. community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, Lucena is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000. She will use the money to expand the quantity and variety of her inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business, and hopes that it will continue to grow. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work.

* All CCT community partners & clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: to expand the quantity and variety of her inventory

loans.name: Thu

texts.en: Thu T. K. N. is 40 years old with two children who are attending secondary school. Ms. Thu is a farmer. Her main activities are growing rice and raising fish. Every day she sells fish to increase her daily income. She has participated in a credit program since 2006. She has borrowed three times and the loans have been used very effectively in her business. Currently, she wants to borrow 8,502,000 dong (VND) to buy food and seed.

loans.use: To buy food  and seed

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
This is Leonida B., 52, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Francisco B., a machine operator. They are blessed in their marriage and have good and healthy physiques which enable them to work for their future together.

Leonida operates a variety store. She also sidelines as an Avon lady, direct selling cosmetics of this popular brand. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil or an egg. She makes a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people of the local community. She earns a minimum of 350 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 8,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Leonida dreams of giving all her children a high quality education with all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Pamela Jepkosgei

texts.en: Pamela is a 38-year-old mother of four, married to Mr K..She sells used clothing and materials. She was introduced to KADET by a member. With this first loan, she plans to buy additional used clothes and materials to sell at a profit. She has been in this business for five years making a comfortable income that has fed the family and schooled the children. Her future plan is to own a fully stocked retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing for sale

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en: Amelita J. is a married woman who lives in Palanas, Ginatilan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fish-vending business. Her husband Vicente J., who is 48 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have six children who are between 5 and 24 years old. Amelita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Amelita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for the business so that she could continue to save up for the future and to save more for emergencies. Amelita J. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital for business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 41-year-old married man and father of three school-aged children. He lives in Lebanon. 

He has 17 years of experience as a construction worker. He used to work with entrepreneurs but in 2000 he started working independently. He takes projects upon request of the customers and he was able to build a good business reputation. His business has significantly been developed during this period. He works hard because he is the main provider for his family. His wife, who works as a clothing seller, tries to help him with her business income. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional wood for a new project. His target is to expand his business in the coming years and be able to continue the education of his children.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn D. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mai's Group

texts.en:
Mai T. P. N. is 26 years old. She has a shop that sells mobile phones and phone cards. Her business has run successfully for five years.  As a client of our credit program since 2009, she has used loan amounts effectively to invest in her business. Currently, she wants to  borrow 6,322,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) to buy more mobile phones with new designs to meet customer demand. All the profit she has from the business is used to improve her living conditions.
 
Tam T. N. is 49 years old with two children. She is raising chickens for eggs. She wants to have a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy food for chickens and to provide vaccinations for them.

Hong T.  H. is 41 years old with three children. She is doing farming. Her main activities are growing rice and vegetables. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy fertilizer.

Chung T. H. is 36 years old with two children who are in high school. She is a teacher. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to pay for school fees.

Hoa T. P. N. is 39 years old with two children. She has a grocery shop in a local market. Her business is running well. She needs to borrow  5,014,000 VND to buy more products for her shop.

Quy T. D. is 38 years  old. She makes goods out of paper for the spirits of departed loved ones - a popular business in Vietnam. Her business is very good. She needs to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy raw materials/

Mao T. N. is 59 years old. She is a farmer. Her main activities are  growing rice and raising 10 pigs. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy fertilizer and to buy food for the pigs.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phone with new designs to meet customer demand

loans.name: Simon Kipkosgei

texts.en:
Simon is a 39-year-old gentleman. He is married to Hellen T. and they have been blessed with two children, who are now age 10 and 16.

He was introduced to Kadet by an existing member of the group that he joined. With this second loan, Simon plans to buy additional sheep that he can sell at a profit. He has been doing this business for the last 10 years and with the experience that he has gained, he has been making good profits that can sustain his family.

His future plan is to expand his business to make more profit so that he can educate all his children in the best schools.

loans.use: To buy addittional sheep for sale

loans.name: Veronica Mbose

texts.en:
Veronica is 32 years old and married with two children. Her spouse is employed. Veronica has been selling charcoal for a period of three years now with a monthly profit of about 32,000 Kenya Shillings.

This is her first loan with Kadet and with the loan, she wants to buy more charcoal for resale. With the profit accumulated she intends to boost the business and pay school fees to educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to buy a lorry (truck) for transporting charcoal to small-scale traders.

loans.use: Buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
This is Marites M., 43, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Danilo M., a driver, and is the mother of two children, one of whom is in high school while the youngest is in elementary school.

By the grace of God, Marites has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marites; she, herself, has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Marites operates a pre-school and a canteen which caters to the students. Most private pre-schools like Marites’ cater to children of the immediate community, especially those whose families cannot afford to send them to special learning centers. Children can study there for a fraction of the tuition fees they would usually have to pay to get the same quality of learning they would have got from professional centers. Most pre-schools also offer in-house food and, most of the time, suggestions of attending a local church Sunday school where the children can learn, socialize and play together.

To help her continue operations of her business, Marites is requesting a Php 30,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings for the canteen. She will also invest a portion of the loan in the repair needs of the school and for additional learning materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Marites dreams that all her students will be instilled with faith for the Lord Almighty and fervently prays for each of them. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more food for the canteen, handle repair needs of the school and buy additional learning materials

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en: Bernardo P. is from the village of Rizal. He is 43 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Bernardo owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Bernardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Bernardo is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his 8th from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Porferia

texts.en:
This is Porferia L., 46, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Zacarias L., a laborer, and is the mother of eight children, two of whom are already working, two are in college, one is in high school, and one is in elementary school.

By the grace of God, Porferia has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Porferia; she, herself, has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Porferia maintains a direct-selling business, selling clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, frozen foods and other products through the popular direct-selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, Pampanga’s Best and others. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and this provides the profits that dealers rely on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 650 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Porferia is requesting a Php 9,000 loan which she will use to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Porferia dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to continue serving her fellowmen through her business, for the glory of the Lord Almighty. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Chin T. L., 32, has one small child. She is a skillful tailor. She has been running a shop where she makes dresses and T-shirts for four years. Her business creates 150,000 VND in profit per day for her. She took her first business loan in 2006. Currently, she wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to expand her shop.

loans.use: To expand her shop.

loans.name: Arzykan

texts.en:
Arzykan A. is  a hardworking 48-year-old woman. She finished secondary school, got married early and gave a birth to her four children.  Arzykan and her husband supported each other in all activities and made their family very united. Unfortunately, in 2009, Arzykan’s husband suffered a stroke and died. It was a hard blow to her, but Arzykan had to get it together and move forward. 

Arzykan started selling vegetables at a local market. Her start as an entrepreneur was successful, but she handed the business over to her daughter whose own family was in need.

At that point, Arzykan decided to start her own business in cattle-breeding.  Using her initial capital of 15,000 KGS, she bought milch cows and started to sell milk.  Due to strong efforts, Arzykan has developed her farm and today she has two milch cows and 19 sheep.  Arzykan intends to use the loan of 60,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing one milch cow, which will allow her to sell more milk, and one horse.  

In future, Arzykan plans to hold her son’s marriage and prepare a cozy home for his future family. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and a horse

loans.name: Chilbert

texts.en: Chilbert B. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 43 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Chilbert owns and operates a business providing boarding house accommodation, primarily offering bed and space to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Chilbert joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Chilbert is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his 4th from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P. is from the village of Rizal. She is 50 years old and is married with seven adult children.

Remedios owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from this activity.

In 2007, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

Remedios is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 8th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Angie

texts.en: This is Angie G., 42, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jaime G., a jail officer at the local penitentiary, and is the mother of three children, all of whom are still enrolled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Angie has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them through college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Angie. She was a college undergraduate herself and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children. Angie operates an electronic cellular phone loading station. What she basically does is buy electronic cellular phone load (prepaid cellular phone credits) in huge amounts then sells them for on a retail basis. Profit is generated depending on the network's policy of dealership. She may buy a 3,000 PHP worth of load for 2,500 PHP, where she makes a 500 PHP profit, depending on promos and quota set by the networks. Angie is also currently readying a few pigs for slaughter and buying and selling a variety of products. To help her continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products to be incorporated into her buy-and-sell inventory. She will also invest some of the loan to buy electronic load from different local networks. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Angie dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her businesses. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. About CCT All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy more products to be incorporated into her inventory and buy electronic load

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 27 year old married man with one child. He is the main income provider for his family. He has five years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2008.

He cultivates all types of vegetables and fruits according to the season. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work.  In the future, he plans to further expand his business and cultivate exotic fruits.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies

loans.name: Julia

texts.en: Julia S. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old, widowed and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Julia owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Julia has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Julia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Julia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Julia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Dismas Kundu

texts.en:
Dismas M. is 61 years old and married to Rosemary Tsetse who helps earn income from their farm. They have three children aged 30,28 and 17 years old. He has been operating a quarry business for the past six years and earns a monthly profit of approximately 34,000 Kenya shillings a month. This is his first loan and he intends to use it to buy tools and equipments for his current business.  


He hopes to buy a vehicle for transporting goods and dreams of building a bigger business and later buy a lorry for stone transportation.

loans.use: Purchase equipment for quarrying

loans.name: Perlina

texts.en:
This is Perlina S., 56, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jess S., a chef. She is the mother of five children, one of whom is still in high school. By the grace of God, Perlina has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Perlina, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Perlina operates a food stall and alS. works as a direct selling agent. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families  eat home-cooked meals during the evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only a family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php15, 000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 
 
Perlina dreams that her business will continue to grow. She alS. hopes that her house can be repaired and renovated someday soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings

loans.name: James Nduaci

texts.en:
James is a 34 years business man married to Ann Njeri. Together they have three children, aged between two years and eight years old. He has been operating a motorcycle transport business for the past three years earning a monthly profit of approximately 19,350 Kenya shilling.  

James will be accessing his second loan with Kadet. He has successfully repaid the first loan. He intends to use the loan to buy spare parts for his motorcycle and to service it. He wants to use the accumulated profit to improve the living standard of his family and buy another motorcycle. 

He hopes to grow and change from the motorcycle to vehicle transport (Matatu) in the future.

loans.use: Buying spare parts for motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year- old single man from Lebanon. He has five years of experience working as a farmer. Despite his young age, he has been running his own farm since 2008. He cultivates all type of fruits according to the season in addition of cultivating olives. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. This allows him to better monitor product quality during the year. His father owns a van and he handles the delivery of the harvest to the agriculture markets. He helps his father with the household.  

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work.  He estimates that with the coming harvest, his profits will be increased.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie P. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 24 years old. Melanie is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Melanie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Melanie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
