loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en: Consolacion A. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte. She is 61 years old and is married with six adult children. Consolacion owns and operates a furniture-making business, making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Consolacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Consolacion is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be her 3rd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
This is Leonora C., 59, a resident of the Municipality of Gen. Mariano Alvarez, Cavite, Philippines. Since she has been widowed, Leonora has been both father and mother to her five children, and grandmother to her darling grandchild. She is blessed with a good and healthy physique which enables her to work hard for her family.

Leonora operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Leonora earns by buying supplies at the wholesale price and selling retail in single quantities. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 350 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Leonora is requesting a Php 35,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Leonora dreams of being able to give her grandchild a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets every week with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of five school-age children.

He opened a mini-market as his own business so as to earn his own income to raise his big family. He has owned his small grocery store since 2004.

With his loan of $1,000 requested from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will increase his store’s inventory before the coming holidays. In the coming year, he expects that his business will continue to grow. 

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets, selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships is an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: To increase his store’s inventory

loans.name: Estrelito

texts.en:
This is Estrelito S., 43, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Imelda S., a housewife, and is the father of four children.

Estrelito operates a piggery while overseeing his tricycle business. While waiting for the swine to be old enough to be slaughtered and sold for meat, Estrelito does his tricycle routes to support the everyday expenses of the family and to buy feeds for the pigs.

To help him continue operations of his businesses, Estrelito is requesting a Php 12,000 loan which he will use to buy more feeds for the swine. He will also invest a portion of the loan in doing the usual tune-up and maintenance of his tricycle. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his businesses.
 
Estrelito dreams of being able to give all his children a good and high-quality education through all his hard work in his businesses. He also hopes to have his house renovated by the end of the year. He faithfully meets every week with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy feed for his pigs and do tune-up and maintenance of his tricycle

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, not currently in school. Jane has a business selling charcoal and firewood, which she has had for less than a year. To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal and firewood to sell. With the help of the loan, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and be able to buy food and medication for her child. In the future, Jane hopes to own a plot of land. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped improve her prospects for the future by teaching her how to expand a business and be self-reliant. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive micro-finance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional micro-finance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in micro-finance.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Bibiana

texts.en:
This is Bibiana D., 45, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Jesus D., a farmer, and is the mother of four children, two of whom are already finished with school while the other two are currently enrolled. By the grace of God, Bibiana has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her two youngest children to college, a dream of most Filipino parents like Bibiana, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave to their children.

Bibiana operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store retailing groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Bibiana is requesting a Php18,000 loan to buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her enterprise.

Bibiana dreams of renovating her house someday soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups, each composed of 15 to 30 community partners, gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Nguyen

texts.en: Nguyen T. P. is 50 years old with three children. She has a shop selling drinks such as beer, soft drinks and sugar cane water. Her shop is very crowded in the summer. Each month she earns 3,500,000 dong (VND) from her business. She has had loans since 2007 which have been used effectively and repaid promptly. Nguyen T. P. wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to buy a refrigerator.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
This is Marisa Sto. D., 30, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Nepumoceno Sto. D., a driver. She is also the mother of two children: one in high school and one in elementary school. By the grace of God, Marisa has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marisa, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can give to their children.

Marisa operates a variety store; she also oversees operations of their tricycle and maintains their piggery. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail prices by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages in order to expand her product inventory. She expects an increase in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Marisa dreams to be able to give all her children a high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase products for variety store

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong T. T. N. is 30 years old. She has a shop that sells construction materials such as steel, cement, bricks, etc. She makes 4,000,000 dong (VND) profit from it. She has been attending a credit program since 2007, and she has used loans effectively and repaid well. Currently, she wants to borrow 8,502,000 VND to buy more products to meet the demand of customers.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita C., 58, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. Predeceased by her husband Ernesto C., she struggles to work hard to survive and be able to help her family, her siblings and their own families.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store retailing groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php350 in sales everyday.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php24,000 loan to buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her enterprise.

Nenita fervently prays for her mother to recover from a lingering sickness. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Each fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Nshungyezi Tukore, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Stephen G., a member of Nshungyezi Tukore group in Ntungamo, is a 35-year-old married father of three boisterous school children. To shoulder his responsibility of providing for them, he has been operating a consumable items retail shop in Nshungyezi Trading centre, Ntungamo for the past four years. His business has not been without setbacks. Since its beginning, he has had to deal with a number of challenges, such as the lack of steady income. However, his business has remained active because of his hard work and good customer relations. He primarily attributes this to the good working relationship that he has established with his customers. 

In a month, Stephen says he makes more than 200,000 UGX, a figure he admits will not substantively make his business grow in the near future. He is therefore seeking a loan to restock his shop as he looks forward to substantial growth.

loans.use: To restock a shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old married man from Lebanon. He is the father of three school-aged children. He has been working as a constructor specializing in gypsum board work. He has been involved in this occupation since 1999. He is the only provider for his family. He works hard to meet their needs and to pay for his children's schooling. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more wood for his business. He is planning to expand his business in the coming years, and he is optimistic about the progress of his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Surayya

texts.ru:
Surayya S. 52 qoda. Ona zamujem i imeyet 3 detey, doch starshaya kotoroy 21 qod ona zakonchila universitet i vishla zamuj, doch 19 let ona uchitsya v universitete i zanimayetsya tancami, i sin 17 let kotoriy uchitsya v shkole i xochet stat doktorom v budushem. Surayya i eyo semya jivut v Fuzuli regione.

Surayya uje 6 let zanimayetsya etim biznesom prodaji odejdi. Etomu biznessu eyo nauchila podruqa, Seychas Surayya nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit odejdu dlya osenneqo sezona dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en:
Surayya S. is fifty-two years old, married and has three children. They live in Fuzuli region of Azerbaijan. Her oldest daughter is twenty-one years old; one year ago she finished college and got married. Her second daughter is nineteen, she's going to college and enjoys dancing. Her son is seventeen; he goes to school and aspires to become a doctor in the future. For six years Surayya has sold clothes, a trade she learned from a friend. Surayya is asking for a loan of 2000 AZN in order to buy fall clothes for resale and expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
This is Gertrudes A., 62, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Griego A., a Baranggay Captain (local community leader).

Gertrudes has operated a flower farm for ten years now. She basically produces ornamental plants and sells them to her neighbors and to the local community. She has also established a wholesale business, selling outside her community to flower shop owners who buy flowers from Gertrudes in bulk. She earns at least Php 400-500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Gertrudes is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more planting materials and fertilizers needed for her flower farm. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Gertrudes prays for good health for herself and her husband. She faithfully meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more planting materials and fertilizers for her flower farm

loans.name: Suusarbubu

texts.en:
Suusarbubu S. is very good-natured woman.  She lives in Bakai-Ata village in the north of Kyrgyzstan. Suusarbubu with her family are engaged in cattle breeding and the cultivation of kidney beans and perennial herbs.   

Being a persistent person, Suusarbubu works hard to enlarge her business and achieve success – today she has one horse and 20 milch cows, whose milk she sells to the local dairy factory. Her partners from the factory characterize her as a punctual and accurate person.   

Suusarbubu plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS  to expand her herd and purchase mineral fertilizers to manure land that will lead to  an increased harvest and top-quality products. 

With future revenues, Suusarbubu plans to buy a truck for the transportation of milk and meat products to customers and consumers in different regions. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle for milk production and fertilizers

loans.name: Sarah Bete

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 37 years old and married to Joseph Makau. They have four children: 14, 12, 8, and 5 years old. Sarah operates a green grocer business where she earns a monthly profit of approximately 20,800 KES. Her husband earns 9,000 KES.

She has been in this business for about twenty years. This is her first loan with Kadet. Sarah wants to use the loan to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables for her shop. With the profit she makes, she intends to repay the loan and pay school fees for her children.

Sarah hopes to improve the business and move it to wholesale. She also hopes to educate her children to tertiary level (post-secondary).

loans.use: Buy more stock of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 1 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à Begnena, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro,(2ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, MAGNELE YAYA S. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1 hectare  de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA environ par campagne.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the group Benkadi 1 are married woment with an average age of 50, 5 children and living in polygamous families in Begnena, one of the villages in the prefecture of Dioila, in the region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Sori Yiriwaso in order to better organise their business activity in winter. The crops produced, among others, are pearl millet, peanuts and beans. This is their fifth loan and all of their previous loans have been duly repaid. With this new loan, Magnele Yaya S. intends to buy agricultural supplies, products and equipment and to cover the labour costs to cultivate approximately 1 hectare of pearl millet and peanuts. The produce is sold in the towns of Dioila and Massigui after the harvest to a clientele of both men and women. She hopes to generate an average income of approximately 40.000FCFA each harvest.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Main d’œuvre, intrants et petits équipements

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice O. is 25  years old and married to Elly Osindi who is a casual employee at Old Nyanza hosipital. They are blessed with two children ages five years and two years respectively. Eunice does maize roasting at Kisumu stage which is a very busy place. She is able to sell hot maize to her clients. Eunice has been in this business for about two years and she is able to get a profit of Kshs.7,000 per month. Her husband's work also contributes to part of the family income. 

Eunice learned about KADET LTD from a friend. She is applying for her first loan of Kshs.10,000 from KADET. She plans to buy more stock of fresh maize for her business. The anticipated income will be used to diversify her business to also sell roasted groundnuts.

Eunice's hopes are to give her children a better education and to support her elderly parents who are living in the village.

loans.use: To add stock of fresh maize to roast

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 2 est constitué de 10 femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 36 ans, 3 enfants et qui vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Begnena, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro,(2ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide, le pois de terre, le sésame et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AWA T. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1,3 hectare d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues sur place, au niveau de la ville de Dioïla  après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice de 80.000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi 2 is made of up of 10 married women with an average age of 36 and 3 children. The majority live in polygamous famiilies in Begnena, one of the villages in the Diola prefecture, Koulikoro region (2nd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organise their winter business activities. The crops cultivated are pearl millet, peanuts, bambara groundnuts, sesame and beans. This is their fifth loan and all of their previous loans have been duly repaid. With this new loan, Awa T. intends to purchase the agricultural products, supplies and equipment and to cover the labour costs required to cultivate approxiamtely 1.3 hectaires of peanuts and beans. The products are sold on site, in Dioila town after the harvest to a clientele of both men and women. After the harvest she hopes to make a profit of approximately 80.000FCFA.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Main d’œuvre, intrants et petits équipements

loans.name: Charles Ndoria

texts.en:
Charles is a 40-year-old businessman.  He is married to Dinah Kanini, and they have a son who is six years old. He has been operating a barber shop for about four years now. His wife owns a hair and beauty salon which generates an income of approximately 400 Kenyan Shillings a day. 

Charles intends to use the loan that he has applied for to buy more beauty products and open a charcoal business. This is his third loan; he has been paying back the previous two successfully. He intends to reinvest the profit generated from this loan in the salon and charcoal business.  In the future, Charles hopes to upgrade his barber shop by buying modern machines for it, and to supply beauty products and cosmetics to other salons in the Juja area. He also dreams of engaging in the wholesale distribution of charcoal.

loans.use: to buy beauty products for his salon and start a charcoal business

loans.name: Michael Kamoni

texts.en:
Michael Kamoni is a single motorbike operator in the area of Thika. He has been in the business for about one year now and he says that he is able to take home a monthly profit of approximately 11,940 Kenyan Shillings. 

This is Michael’s second loan with KADET; he repayed his previous loan successfully. With the profit he wants to buy more motorcycles so he can establish and manage a serious motorcycle business. He hopes to own at least five more motor cycles very soon.

loans.use: to buy more motorcycles

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi 3 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et   4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Begnena, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations cultivées par ce groupe de femmes sont  le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, KARIATOU S., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1 hectare d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi 3 group are all married women who are on the average 37 years old, with four children. They live mainly in polygamous families in Begnena, a village in the Diola prefecture, Koulikoro region (the 2nd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal to be able to better manage their agricultural activities during the winter season. They cultivate pearl millet, peanuts and beans. They are now on their fifth agricultural loan, with all previous loans duly repaid. With this new loan, Kariatou S., the group’s leader, plans to purchase agricultural inputs and small tools as well as pay for the labor to work a peanut field of about 1 hectare [2.5 acres]. After harvesting, the produce is sold in the towns of Diola and Massigui, to a customer base composed of both men and women. After this season, the group members plan to achieve an average revenue of about 35,000 West African Francs each.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, agricultural inputs and small tools

loans.name: Gulyaz

texts.ru:
Gulyaz T. 52 qoda. Ona zamujem i imeyet 4 detey,doch 22 let uje zamujem i v toje vremya rabotayet v detskom sadu vospitatelnicey, doch 20 let uchitsya v universitete i pomoqayet materi po rabote, sin 17 let uchitsya v shkole,doch 16 let uchitsya v shkole i lubit risovat. Gulyaz i yeyo semya jivut v Fuzuli regione.

Gulyaz uje 7 let kak rabotayet v etom biznese. Etomu biznessu eyo nauchila sestra kotoraya toje prodayet. Gulyaz seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit tovar dlya pereprodaji .Kak vi videte na fotoqrafii Gulyaz prodayet na ulice no krome etoqo ona prodayet eshe i doma svoim sosedyam i znakomim kto yeyo znayet.Doma za prodajey tovarov smotrit yeyo dochki etim oni pomoqayut mame po rabote.
texts.en:
Gulyaz T. is 52 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Her 22-year-old daughter is already married and also works as a kindergarten teacher. Her 20-year-old daughter attends a university and helps her mother with work. Her 17-year-old son goes to school, and her 16-year-old daughter goes to school too and likes to draw. Gulyaz and her family live in the Fuzuli region. Gulyaz has been working in this business for 7 years. Her sister, who is also in sales, taught Gulyaz this business. Now Gulyaz needs 2000 AZN in order to buy goods for resale. As you can see on the photo, Gulyaz sells goods on the street and also sells at home to her neighbors and acquaintances. At home, her daughters look after the goods sales and that is how they help their mother with work.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods for resale

loans.name: Benkadi I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENKADI I sont des femmes mariées avec en moyenne 43 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants, qui vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à N’Gala, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités agricoles. 
Elles cultivent le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, FILY S., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre pour entretenir environ 1,6 hectare de petit mil, d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice moyen de 50 000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
he ten members of the Benkadi I group are married women who are on the average 43 years old, with five children; they live mainly in polygamous families in N’Gala, a village in the Diola prefecture, in the Koulikoro region (the 2nd administrative district of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better manage their agricultural business. They cultivate pearl millet, peanuts and beans. They are on their second agricultural loan, having duly repaid the previous loan. With this new loan, Fily S., the group’s leader, plans to purchase agricultural inputs, small tools and pay the cost of labor to work about 1.6 hectares [approx.4 acres] of pearl millet, peanuts and beans. After harvesting, the produce is sold in the town of Diola and in Massigui, to a customer base composed of both men and women. After this agricultural season the group members plan to earn an average revenue of about 50,000 West African Francs each.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, weeding, fertilizers, herbicides and small tools

loans.name: Benkadi Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENKADI II sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, 4 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygames à N'Gala, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, AMATOU S. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre pour entretenir environ 1,5 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs. 
Elles comptent réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice moyen de 50 000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi II group are married women who are on average 41 years old and have 4 children. They mainly live in polygamous families in N'Gala, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, Koukiro region, Second Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali. They have been working with Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities during the rainy season. They cultivate millet, groundnut and beans as cash crops. They are on their second planting loan and the first one was repaid on time. With this new loan, Amatou S. plans to buy supplies and small equipment and to pay for the labour costs to maintain about 1.5 hectares of millet and groundnut. After the harvest, the crops will be sold in Massigui to a clientele of consumers and resellers. They hope to earn an income of 50,000 francs on average from this planting.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labour, engrais, herbicide, sarclage et petits équipements

loans.name: Benkadi Iii Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI III est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à N’Gala, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, le pois de terre, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SIRA S. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre pour entretenir environs 1, 2 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
BENKADI III is a group of 10 married women on average 35 years old, with 3  children, that live in polygamous families in N’Gala, one of the villages of the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso to be able to better organize their winter activities. The crops they cultivate include millet, blackeyed peas, groundnut and beans. This is the group's second loan and the first one had been repaid as planned. With this new loan, SIRA S. plans to buy fertilizer and small tools and hire help to maintain about 1.2 hectares of millet and groundnut. The crops are sold in the cities of Dioïla and Massigui after harvest, to both men and women. The members of the group hope to make a profit of approximately 40 000 CFA.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Benkadi IV est constitué de 10 femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à N’Gala, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations cultivées sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, FATOUMATA SEYDOU D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de main d’œuvre  pour entretenir environ 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après la récolte à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice de 85.000FCFA.
texts.en:
Benkadi IV is made up of 10 married women, on average 39  years old and with 3 children. Most of them live in polygamous families in N’Gala, one of the villages of the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, the seond administrative region of Mali. The women of the group work with Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their winter activities. The crops they cultivate include millet, groundnut and beans. This is their second loan and the first one was correctly repaid. With this new loan FATOUMATA SEYDOU D. plans to buy fertilizer and small tools and hire help to maintain about 1 hectare of groundnut. The production is sold in the city of Dioïla after harvest, to resellers mostly. The members of the group expect to make a profit of 85 000 FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicide, tilling and small tools

loans.name: Manko Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité MANKO est formé de 20 membres. Il a vu le jour la veille du financement du Banc Villageois le 04/12/2007. Elles sont des femmes très entreprenantes unies par des liens d'affinité et de voisinage. Elle s'entraident et de mènent des activités commerciales

MAME BOURY N. debout à l'extrême droit sur la photo, vêtue de bleu, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 39 ans. Elle est veuve et vit avec ses deux enfants. 

Elle vend des parfums et ustensiles de cuisine, des tabourets. Elle s'approvisionne à Dakar et revend sa marchandise à Louga.

Son crédit lui permettra de renforcer son niveau d'approvisionnement en marchandises ci-dessus pour augmenter ses revenus financiers.

Son objectif est de prendre en charge de la gestion familiale et de renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
The MANKO solidarity group, consisting of 20 members, was created on the eve of the inauguration of the Banc Villageois (04/12/2007). These are very enterprising women who came together because they share an affinity and they are neighbors. They help each other, and they engage in commercial activities. MAME BOURY N., standing at the far right in the photo and dressed in blue, is the head of the group. She is a 39-year-old widow who lives with her two children. She sells perfumes, cooking utensils, and stools. She gets her stocks in Dakar and sells the merchandise in Louga. Her loan will allow her to increase her stocks and boost her income. Her goal is to support her family and bolster her savings.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy perfumes, cooking utensils, and stools

loans.name: Benkadi V Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI V sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 2 enfants et vivent dans des familles polygames à N’Gala, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités agricoles. 
Les spéculations cultivées par ces femmes du groupe BENKADI V sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide, le maïs, le pois de terre et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, WARABA D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,2 hectare  d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser après la campagne, un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA environ.
texts.en:
The members of the BENKADI V group are married women, on average 32 years old with 2 children, and they live in polygamous families in N’Gala, one of the villages of the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microlending institution in order to better organize their agricultural activities. The crops they cultivate include millet, groundnut, corn, blackeye pea and beans. This is the group's second loan, the first one has been repaid properly. With this new loan, WARABA D. plan to buy fertilizer and small tools, as well as hire help to maintain about 1.2 hectares of groundnut and beans. Their harvest is sold in the cities of Dioïla and Massigui, to both men and women. They hope to make an average profit of approximately 40 000 CFA.

Translated from French by Loïc Haméon, Kiva Volunteer

Elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.

The members of the Benkadi VII Group are ten married women who are on average 24 years old with two children. Most live in polygamous families in N’Gala, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture, part of the Koulikouro region in the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI with the intent of better organising their wintering activities. Their cash crops are among others millet, peanuts and beans. loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicides, weeding and small farming equipment

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 45 years old, and a married father of 4 children between the ages of 1 and 13. Three of his children attend school. David has been practising mixed farming in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya, for the last four years. He has employed one person from his community. He sells his milk at the local market and eggs to local hotels. He is also employed by the Teachers’ Service Commission and earns income from his small-scale farming of tea, which he sells to a local factory.

David has requested this loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to expand his poultry farming operation. He says that this loan will enable him to purchase equipment which will increase his egg production and sales. The extra income from this loan will help him meet the needs of his family. His biggest challenges have been poultry diseases and poor markets for his products. He hopes to turn his poultry farming into a higher income-generating business in the future.

loans.use: to expand his poultry farming

loans.name: Lynn

texts.en:
Lynn is 48 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children.  She is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. She has been farming for the last fifteen years and has employed two farmhands. Lynn sells her milk at the local market. She is employed by the Public Service Commission and also earns income from her small-scale farming of tea, which she sells to the Kenya Tea Development Authority. Her major challenges in farming have been the high cost of animal feed, and a lack of labour and good artificial insemination services. 

Lynn has requested this loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will help increase her milk production, thus increasing her income. The extra income from this loan will help her meet the financial obligations of her family. She hopes to upgrade the quality of her dairy cows to a more productive breed in the future.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He is 42 years old, married and has been blessed with four school-aged children. He has been farming for five years and employs two farmhands. He sells his milk at a local market. He also earns income from small-scale farming of tea which he sells to a local tea factory. He faces the challenges of lack of animal feed and animal diseases due to lack of enough information on preventive measures. 

Simion has requested this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimoto to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this loan will enable him to acquire an additional asset that will be used as security for future loans and will increase the income of his family through the sale of milk. He hopes to improve his farm to be a more productive and profitable business in the future. He is grateful to Juhudi for their support.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David has been practising dairy farming for eight years in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. He sells his milk to a nearby tea estate. He employs two people from his community. He also practises small-scale farming of tea which he sells to a local tea factory. He faces the challenges of lack of enough animal feed and a poor road network to the market.

David is 43 years old. He is married with seven children who are now between the ages of 2 and 18. Six of the children attend school. 

David has requested this loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that with an increase in the number of his dairy cows his production will increase, and this will earn the family extra income that will help pay school fees for the children. In five years' time, he hopes his business will grow into a profit-making business with five dairy cows that are productive. He is grateful to the company for their assistance.

texts.en:
David is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for three years and has employed one farmhand. He sells his milk at a local market. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea which he sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority factory.

David is 32 years old. He is married with 3 school-aged children.

He has requested this loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this dairy cow will increase his production and he will earn enough income to enable him to meet the basic needs of his family. His biggest challenges have been animal diseases and lack of enough animal feed. He however hopes to improve the quality of his dairy cows in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Benno Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité BENNO est formé de 18 membres. Il a vu le jour la veille du financement du Banc Villageois le 04/12/2007. Ce sont des femmes qui ont organisé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de NOP SA JËKËR 

Madame FATOU N., debout tout à fait à droite sur la photo, avec une pochette jaune à la main, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 36 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants en charge. 

Elle est couturière en même temps restauratrice, elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans. 

Son crédit lui permettra d'une part d'acheter des tissus qu'elle coud et revend dans son quartier. Et d'autre part, acheter des provisions pour faire des prestations en restauration

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la gestion financière de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benno solidarity group is made up of 18 members. It was established the day before the financing of the Banc Villageois on 4th December 2007. The women who set up this group are friends and neighbors. The group is part of the Banc Villageois in Nop sa Jëkër. Mrs. Fatou N., who is standing on the right of the photo with a yellow bag in her hand, is responsible for the group. She is 36 years old, married and mother to four children, who are in her care. She is a seamstress and at the same time owns a restaurant; she has been carrying out these activities for more than five years. Her loan will allow her to buy fabric which she sews and resells in her neighborhood. It will also allow her to buy provisions for her restauration service. Her objective is to support her husband in the financial management of the family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop her sewing and restauration businesses

loans.name: Mti Mrefu Group

texts.en:
Mary C., who is in her early forties, is married with three children who are in school.  She has operated a pharmacy shop since 2008.  She works from 8am to 8 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about US$ 197.

This will be Mary’s 1st "motisha" loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A "motisha" loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.  She will use this loan to buy more medicines.  Her dream is to start selling medicines at wholesale prices.
	
Mary will share this loan with her loan group,  Mti  Mrefu, which has 10 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture Mary is wearing green and black.

loans.use: To buy more medicines for her pharmacy

loans.name: Silferias Aluodo

texts.en:
Silferias O. is an electrician who runs a small shop that deals with electronics items. He has been in this business for 10 years and earns an income of Kshs.30,000 per month. The business is situated in Kisumu town in a busy place.
 
O. is 30 years old and married to Naomi Atieno who sells plastic products; her income adds to the family income. They are still a young couple and have no children. He learnt about KADET LTD from a friend and  got interested to take his first loan from KADET LTD,  where he plans to purchase more electronic products to add to his stock.

He plans to use the anticipated income to plow back into his business by adding enough stock to sustain the business and satisfy the needs of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase electronics products

loans.name: Philiph

texts.en:
Philiph has a dairy farm on the outskirts of Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been managing his farm for four years and has employed one farmhand. He sells his milk to the local hotels. He also earns income from the sale of tea and from his masonry business.

Philiph has requested this loan of 20,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes that his income will increase and enable him to meet the needs of his family. He plans to acquire more dairy cows, going from the current three to five, and build a modern dairy unit in future. His primary challenges have been animal diseases and the lack of good markets for milk.

Philiph is 49 years old. He is married with 6 children who are between the ages of 2 and 24. Two of the children attend school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Crane Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth A., who is in her early forties, is married and has a daughter of 17.  She has a retail shop and has been selling different types of liquid soap since 2007.   She works from 6am to 10pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about US$ 53.

This will be Elizabeth’s 4th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to open the retail shop and to purchase a small piece of land. She has successfully paid back her loan.  She will use the current loan to build her house foundation.

Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group, Crane, which totals 21 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 
	
In the picture, Elizabeth is in the front row holding her product in her hands.

loans.use: To build a house foundation

loans.name: Thiat Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité THIAT est composé de 13 femmes. Ces femmes se sont organisées par affinité et par voisinage. Elles sont des femmes très entreprenantes et très rigoureuses dans le travail. le groupe a vu le jour la veille du financement du Banc Villageois. 

Madame AÏDA S., debout à droite sur la photo, en pantalon noir et tee-shirt blanc, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 24 ans. Elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant en charge. 

Elle s'active dans la vente de produits cosmétiques. Elle achète la marchandise dans des contenaires en provenance du Mali 

Son crédit lui permettra d'augmenter son niveau d'approvisionnement afin d'accroître ses bénéfices.

Son objectif est de subvenir à ses besoins personnels et de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
The THIAT solidarity group consists of 13 women who were brought together by affinity, and because they are neighbors. They are very enterprising women, and rigorous workers. The group was created on the eve of the Banc Villageois inauguration. Mrs. AÏDA S. is the head of the group. She is seen standing at the right of the photo in black trousers and a white T-shirt. She is 24 years old, married, and the mother of a dependent child. She sells cosmetic products, which she buys in containers from Mali. Her loan will allow her to increase her stocks and boost her profits. Her goal is to be able to meet her personal needs and support her husband in providing for the family.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetic products

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en: Franklin O. M.  is married and has three children ages 12, 8 and 4. They go to school.  He is 33 years old and has been doing carpentry for fourteen years in a busy environment.  He employs two people in his business. Apart from carpentry, Franklin runs a retail shop while his wife runs a boutique.  He also does quarrying for extra income. Franklin has requested for a loan of 60, 000 KES to add stock of timber, to buy a drilling machine, add bags of sugar, maize flour and to buy explosives for quarrying.  With his profits, Franklin hopes to open a bigger workshop and expand his quarrying business.

loans.use: To add stock of timber, buy a drilling machine, add bags of sugar, maize flour and buy explosives for quarrying.

loans.name: Ruvuma Group

texts.en:
Paulo M. is single and in his late twenties.  He has been selling pork for about two years.  He works from 11am to 10pm and he is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Paulo’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to increase  the pork stock and has paid back his loan successfully. He will use this loan to buy a deep freezer.  Paulo’s dream is to open more pork shops in different areas.

Paulo will share this loan with his loan group, Ruvuma, which totals 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 
	
In the picture, Paulo is 1st on the left standing.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer.

loans.name: Jashon Ochola

texts.en:
Jashon O. is 33 years old , a business man who sells water at the Nyalenda estate in Kisumu town. He is married to Stella Anyango who also sells water and contributes to the family income. They are blessed with two children ages three years and five years old. Jashon has been in this business for one year, and his monthly income is Kshs.10,000

O. is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD to open up another water kiosk. He plans to use the anticipated income to pay back his loan.

loans.use: To open up another water kiosk

loans.name: Morris

texts.en: Morris M. M. is 28 years old and married with one child.  He has been running his retail shop for only one year.  In addition, he runs a cafeteria and a butcher shop. He was previously working as a shopkeeper before he decided to open his own shop.  He is a member of Faulu Kenya under a group called Imani but has never taken out a loan.  Now, he wants to take out a loan of 80,000 Kes.  With the loan, he will add stock of mobile phone air time, rice, sugar and soda.  He hopes to improve his business in the future.  In ten years, he wants to buy a plot and build his own business premises.

loans.use: To add stock of mobile phone air time, rice, sugar and soda.

loans.name: Mikumi Group

texts.en:
Anjelina P., who is in her late thirties, is married with 5 sons and one daughter.   She has operated several different businesses for the past 10 years.  Angelina operates a retail shop where she sells food items, including Irish potatoes.  She also has a food vending business.  And if these two businesses did not keep her busy enough, she also sells fabric door-to-door.  She is really a hard working lady.  She works from 6am to 8pm and she is able to make a good monthly profit.  

This will be Anjelina’s 11th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.   She used the previous loans to open her retail shop and food vending business.  She has paid back her loans successfully. She will use this loan to increase  the shop inventory and to buy more Irish potatoes.

Anjelina will share this loan with her loan group, Mikumi, which totals 16 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. 
	
In the picture, Anjelina is in orange.

loans.use: To increase the retail shop stock and buy more sacks of Irish potatoes.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is a member of Neema group that is  part of  Faulu Kenya.  Moses  sells bags.  He was previously employed before he went into business. He hopes to expand his business to improve his standard of living.  He has requested for a loan of 30,000 Kes to buy more bags for sale.  This will be his first loan from Faulu Kenya.  He hopes that in the future, he will run a big shop for selling bags.

loans.use: To buy a variety of bags

loans.name: Royal Group

texts.en:
Pelegrin M., who is in his early sixties, is married with 5 children. Pelegrin is a music performer and a manager of a band.  He has managed the band since 2005.  He works daily from 7am until 12pm and he is able to earn a monthly profit of around $132.

This will be Pelegrin’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He will use the loan to repair and improve on the band's music system. He is hard working and very busy especiA. the nights when he performs.  

Pelegrin will share this loan with his loan group, Royal, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other responsible for paying back their loans. 

In the picture, Pelegrin is in front in a green shirt.

loans.use: To repair and improve on the band's music system.

loans.name: Sope Serigne Babacar Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE SERIGNE BABACAR est né le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 15 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de NDIABOOT.

Madame MBAMOUSSE K., debout à droite de la photo, les bras croisés et tenant son livret d'épargne et de crédit entre les mains, est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 44 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants en charge. 

Elle fait du commerce d'arachide et de pastèque. Elle mène cette activité depuis environs 05 ans.

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son niveau d'approvisionnement en marchandises ci-dessus afin d'augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire. 

Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et participer à la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
The Sope Serigne Babacar solidarity group was created on December 5, 2007. It is composed of 15 women all living in the same neighborhood. They are friends and neighbors who decided to form a group together. The group belongs to the Banc Villageois of Ndiaboot. Mrs. Mbamousse K., standing on the right in the photo, with her arms crossed and holding her bank book, is the group’s leader. She is 44 years old. She is married and the mother of six dependent children. She sells peanuts and watermelons. She has been doing this for about 5 years. Her new loan will allow her to bolster her level of merchandise stock in order to increase her profit margin. Her goal is to grow her savings and to contribute to the family budget.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing peanuts and watermelons

loans.name: Ushirika Mazizini Group

texts.en:
Cleopa M., who is in his late twenties, is married with six children.  He has been a butcher for the past two years.  He works from 6am to 8pm and he has been able to earn a good monthly profit.

This will be Cleopa’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loan to buy more kilos of meat and he has successfully paid back the loan.  He will use this loan to increase on his meat stock.  Cleopa currently uses a knife to cut up his meat.  His dream is to open a first class butchery shop with a special meat cutter.

Cleopa will share this loan with his loan group, Ushirika Mazizini,  which totals 17 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Cleopa is in front 1st on the right.

loans.use: To buy more stock of meat.

loans.name: Leonor Mercedes

texts.es:
Leonor de 62 años, es viuda y vive en una zona suburbana del Suburbio, tiene un centro de llamadas. 

Cuando murió su esposo ella inicio el negocio para poder estar económicamente estable. Con la ayuda de su hijo pudo comprar algunas cabinas telefónicas y tener su centro de llamadas. Ahora ella trabaja desde las 07h30am hasta las 22h30pm.Una de las dificultades que tiene para su negocio es que no tiene mucha seguridad ya en algunas ocasiones los ladrones le han robado. 

Para que su negocio siga con mas éxito ella quiere comprar con el préstamo una maquina de recargas celulares.  En el futuro quiere mejorar su negocio y seguir unida a su familia.
texts.en:
Leonor is a 62 year old widow. She lives in the rural area of Suburbio. She has a call center. She started this business in order to have financial stability when her husband died. With her son’s help she was able to buy some telephone booths and have a call center. She now works from 7:30 a.m. until 10:30 p.m. One of the difficulties that she has with her business is that it is not very safe. She has been robbed on a few occasions. In order for her business to continue with more success, she wants to use the loan to buy a machine that recharges cell phones. In the future she wants to improve her business and to continue being a close-knit family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Machine to recharge cell phones

loans.name: Nob Sa Jëkër Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité NOB  SA JËKËR est né le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 18 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier. Elles se sont organisées par affinité et par voisinage. Le groupe de solidarité fait partie du Banc Villageois de NDIABOOT.

Madame NDATTE D., debout tout à fait à droite sur la photo avec un foulard noir sur la tête, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 41 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. 

Elle est vendeuse de poissons frais au marché de son quartier. Elle s'approvisionne sur place auprès des mareyeurs en provenance des villages de pêcheurs. Elle fait cette activité depuis 4 ans.

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son commerce de poissons frais en augmentant son niveau d'approvisionnement.

Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
The solidarity group NOB SA JËKËR was created on December 5, 2007. It is composed of 18 women who all come from the same neighborhood. They established their group based on friendship and neighborhood. The solidarity group is affiliated with the NDIABOOT Banc Villageois. Mrs. NDATTE D., standing at the far right in the photo with a black scarf on her head, is the leader of the group. She is 41 years old, married and the mother of 5 children. She sells fresh fish at the market in her neighborhood. She gets her provisions on site from fish wholesalers from fishing villages. She has operated this business for 4 years. Her new loan will enable her to expand her fresh fish business by bolstering her stock. Her goal is to build her savings and to help her husband provide for the family’s financial needs.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell fish

loans.name: Mercedes Del Rosario

texts.es: La  Sra. Mercedes del Rosario B.   ella  es Trabajadora del colegio público “CERMA” de San Rafael del Sur  desempeñándose como Maestra de Educación Primaria tiene  Veinte y seis  año de trabajar para el magisterio . Ha tenido  ocho créditos con CEPRODEL y los ha realizado para comprar materiales de construcción para mejorar su casa de habitación y este lo está solicitando para la compra de cosmético porque ella  aparte de ser maestra se dedica a la venta de cosmético y le vende a sus mismas compañeras de trabajo del mismo colegio, los cuales los créditos con Ceprodel le han beneficiado en gran manera ya que de esa manera ella ha  mejorado su condición de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mercedes del Rosario B. has been employed as a teacher for 26 years. She is currently employed as an Elementary School Teacher at “CERMA” School in San Rafael del Sur. She has had 8 loans with CEPRODEL that she’s used to buy building materials and supplies for home improvements. This loan, however, is to buy cosmetics because besides being a teacher she also sells cosmetics to her coworkers at school. Ceprodel loans have been of great benefit to her in that they have improved her and her family’s living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For perfume and make-up.

loans.name: Juan José

texts.es: El Sr. Juan José N. C.   él  se desempeña  como Conserje en el Colegio público “CERMA”, tiene  tres años de trabajar para esta institución, tiene dos niños en edad escolar, es casado actualmente. Ha tenido  tres créditos con CEPRODEL y los ha realizado para comprar materiales de construcción para mejorar su casa de habitación los cuales los créditos con ceprodel le han beneficiado en gran manera ya que de esa manera él  ha  mejorado su condición de vida de él y su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan José N. C. has been employed as a caretaker at “CERMA” Public School for three years. He’s married and has two school age children. He has had three CEPRODEL loans that he’s used to buy building materials and supplies for home improvements. Ceprodel loans have been of great benefit to him in that they have improved his and his family’s living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For zinc metal sheeting and tubing and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Ileana Del Socorro

texts.es: La señora Ileana tiene 31 años de edad, de los cuales 16 años los ha  pasado trabajando en su negocio que es el servicio de belleza ambulante,  ella atiende a sus clientes de la mejor manera posible pues siempre está pendiente de los diferentes pedidos que le realizan. Además de este negocio la señora vende productos de la Avon para así ayudarse un poco mas con los ingresos familiares madre de dos hijos que se encuentran en el colegio. Su esposo trabaja como contratista por temporadas. Es por ello que la señora recurre a financiamientos para a si mejorar las condiciones de su negocio ya que necesita ciertos productos como pinturas de uñas, pintura de labios, toallas, cortaúñas, entre otros.
texts.en:
Sra. Ileana is 31 years old and has spent the past 16 years working in her business in which she provides mobile beauty services. She attends to her customers in the best way possible and always tries to provide them with the different services they request. In addition to this business, Ileana sells Avon products to help earn a little more income for her family. She is the mother of two children who are in high school. Her husband works as a seasonal contractor.

Ileana has returned to request a loan so that she can improve the conditions of her business. She needs to acquire certain products such as nail polish, lipsticks, towels, nail clippers, and other supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase nail polish, lipsticks, towels, nail clippers, and other supplies

loans.name: Las Rosas De San Mateo Group

texts.es:
LAS ROSAS D. SAN MATEO:  SE LOCALIZA EN  LA COMUNIDAD D. SAN MATEO MILPAS ALTAS ANTIGUA GUATEMALA HACE 18 MESES, QUE SE FORMO, CON 12 SEÑORAS QUE SE DEDICAN  A LA AGRICULTURA, TORTILLERIA Y GANADO   UTILIZANDO CREDITO D. FAPE.EL BANCO LAS ROSAS D. SAN MATEO HA LLEGADO A SU CUARTO CICLO GRACIAS AL CREDITO D. FAPE, SU LIDER DOÑA ELIDA T. Q.,CASADA, CON 10 HIJOS ESTUDIAN 6 EN LA ESCUELA LOCAL 5 Y EN DIVERSIFICADO  1 EN ANTIGUA GUATEMALA  LLEVANDO LA CARRERA D. MAESTRA D. PRIMARIA, VIVEN CON ELLA 9  EN UNA COMUNIDAD PEQUEÑA.LOS SUEÑOS D. DOÑA ELIDA , SON QUE SUS HIJOS SIGAN ESTUDIANDO Y ALCANZAR UNA MEJOR OPORTUNIDAD EN EL FUTURO,SU ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES LA AGRICULTURA, SIEMBRA D. EJOTE, ARVEJA CHINA, ARVEJA CRIOLLA, LLEVA 10 AÑOS  D.  TRABAJAR EN SU PROPIO TERRENO CON AYUDA D. SU ESPOSO,E HIJOS Y POR TEMPORADA HOBREROS PARTICULARES. INVERTIRA EN SU AGRICULTURA PAGARA PARA QUE  MONTEN Y DESMONTEN EL TERRENO, YA QUE CUENTA CON SEMILLAS Y ABONO PARA REALIZAR SU SIEMBRA, ES NECESARIO PARA QUE TENGA BUENA COSECHA, Y AL FINAL Y ENTREGAR UN BUEN PRODUCTO.
DOÑA ELIDA T. Q., HA TENIDO 3 CREDITOS EN FAPE HA DEMOSTRADO RESPONSABILIDAD Y CAPACIDAD Y SOBRE TODO PUNTUALIDAD EN LOS PAGOS,  MENSUAL, Y SOBRE TODO LO QUE LE ENCANTA ES EL AHORRO FIJO QUE ME SOLICITA, PORQUE SIN DARME CUENTA ESTOY AHORRANDO Y ES UN DINERO QUE FAPE ME LO HA GUARDADO Y ESO ME ALEGRA PORQUE NO ESTA EN MIS MANOS Y LOGRO PAGAR MI CREDITO
texts.en:
“Las Rosas D. San Mateo” (The Roses of San Mateo) is located in the community of San Mateo Milpas Altas in Antigua Guatemala. This group was started eighteen months ago with twelve women who engage in agriculture, tortilla production, and livestock breeding. For this reason, they are utilizing loans from FAPE. The “Rosas D. San Mateo” Bank is in its fourth loan cycle with FAPE. Their leader is Doña Elida T.. She is married and has ten children, nine of whom still live with her in this small community. Six of her children are students at the local school while one lives in Antigua and has a degree in elementary school education. Doña Elida dreams that her children will continue their studies so that they can have better opportunities in the future. Her main business activity is farming. She has been growing green beans, Chinese peas, and Creole peas on her own land for ten years with the help of her husband, children, and seasonal workers. Elida will invest in her farming activities by paying to have her land plowed and cleared. She has the seeds and compost needed for planting because it is necessary for her to have a good harvest and produce a quality crop.

Doña Elida T. Q. has had three previous loans with FAPE and has demonstrated that she is responsible and prompt when making all of her monthly payments. Of all the services, she enjoys the established savings. She is happy with the money she keeps with FAPE because it stays out of her hands and it helps with repaying her loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in farming activities

loans.name: Tacku Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TACKU LIGGEY est né le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 11 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de NDIABOOT

Madame YAH GAYE D.,debout à droite sur la photo, en écharpe noir et foulard rouge sur la tête, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 56 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 07 enfants. 

Elle fait un commerce de riz de la vallée. Elle s'approvisionne à bord champ pour revendre dans sa région à Louga. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 2 ans. 

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son niveau d'approvisionnement afin de constituer un bon stock et satisfaire le plus largement sa clientèle.

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge quotidienne de la famille, et de renforcer son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Tacku Liggey was created on December 5, 2007. It is made up of 11 women, all from the same neighborhood. The group is a part of the Village Bank of Ndiaboot. Mrs. Yah Gaye D., standing to the right in the photo, in the black shawl and red headscarf, is the leader of the group. She is 56 years old. She is married and the mother of 7 children. She sells rice from the valley. She stocks up in the fields on the edge of town to resell in her region of Louga. She has run this business for more than 2 years. Her new loan will allow her to strengthen her supply levels in order to build up a good stock and to satisfy her clientèle to the maximum level possible. Her goal is to support her husband in caring for the daily needs of the family and to strengthen their level of savings.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell local rice

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es: La Sra. María Elena M. G.   ella  es Trabajadora activa  del colegio público “San Cristóbal”  desempeñándose como Maestra de Educación primaria, tiene  ocho  año de trabajar para esta institución. Ha tenido  ocho créditos con CEPRODEL y los ha realizado para comprar materiales de construcción para mejorar su casa de habitación y este crédito lo está solicitando para la reparación de su baño,  los cuales los créditos con Ceprodel le han beneficiado en gran manera ya que de esa manera ella ha  mejorado su condición de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Elena M. G. has been employed as an Elementary School Teacher at “San Cristóbal” Public School for 8 years. She has had loans with CEPRODEL that she’s used to buy building materials and supplies for home improvements. This loan will be used to repair the bathroom. Ceprodel loans have been of great benefit to her in that they have improved her and her family’s quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Por paving stones, sand, cement and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Ayda Del Socorro

texts.es: La Sra. Ayda del Socorro C. G. es trabajadora activa del Colegio “La Fortuna” el crucero tiene  quince años de trabajarle a esta institución desempeñándose como Maestra de Educación primaria. Ha tenido  cinco créditos con CEPRODEL y cada uno lo ha hecho para comprar materiales de construcción y mejorar su casa de habitación los créditos le ha beneficiado en gran manera ya que de esta manera ella  ha  mejorado su condición de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ayda del Socorro C. G. has been working as an Elementary School Teacher at “La Fortuna” School for 15 years. She has had five CEPRODEL loans that have been used to buy building materials and supplies for home improvements. The loans have been of great benefit to her in that they have improved her and her family’s living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paint for her house, cement, zinc metal sheeting and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Amah

texts.fr: D. amah  est une dame de 54 ans. elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce charbons de bois et s'approvisionne à anié à l'intérieur du pays. elle fait ce commerce depuis 2003. elle demande un premier crédit pour s'approvisionner avec 20 sacs de charbons de bois pour pouvoir satisfaire les demandes de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Amah D. is a 54 year old woman. She is married and the mother of 5 children. She runs a business selling charcoal and stocks up in Anié, in the interior of the country. She has run her business since 2003. She is requesting this first loan in order to stock up with 20 bags of charcoal so that she may be able to satisfy the needs of her clients.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Erika Manuela

texts.es: La Sra. Erika Manuela R. C. es trabajadora activa del Colegio “La Fortuna” el crucero tiene  diez  años de trabajarle a esta institución desempeñándose como Maestra de Educación primaria, tiene dos niños en Edad Escolar. Ha tenido  cuatro créditos con CEPRODEL y cada uno lo ha hecho para comprar materiales de construcción y mejorar su casa de habitación los créditos le ha beneficiado en gran manera ya que de esta manera ella ha  mejorado su condición de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Erika Manuela R. C. has been an Elementary School Teacher at “La Fortuna” School for ten years. She has two school age children. She has had four CEPRODEL loans that she used to buy building materials and supplies to do some home improvements. The loans have been of great benefit to her in that they have improved her and her family’s living conditions

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paint for her house, cement, sand and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: M. kossiwa est une dame de 46 ans. elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. malgré son âge avancée elle est une femme très dynamique.  elle exerce depuis trois ans déjà le commerce de charbons de bois. elle s'approvisionne en quantité dans la ville de Kara, ce qui lui permet d'avoir une plus grande marge bénéficiaire sur ses ventes. son stock de marchandises est en baisse, pour se réapprovisionner, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une trentaine de sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandises
texts.en:
Kossiwa M. is a 46 year old woman. She is married and the mother of 3 children. Despite her advanced age, she is a very dynamic woman. For three years she has run a business selling charcoal. She stocks up in large quantities in the city of Kara, which allows her to have a large profit margin on her sales. Her stock of merchandise is low, so in order to restock she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy some 30 bags of charcoal and to assure the transport of her merchandise.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Johanna Elizabeth

texts.es:
